body_text.text: V
Vertical distribution of artifacts and features from Blocks I, J, and K in Area 8. 19 Generalized stratigraphic section of the Lubbock Lake site by Green.

The Lubbock Lake site of Lubbock County, Texas, has been known for some time as one of several famous Paleoindian sites within the southern High Plains area. Its claim to distinction has come mainly from charred bison bone which yielded the first radiocarbon date of 9883 + 350 years B.P. for the Folsom period in North America (Libby, 1955) . Although four major investigations and some minor work have taken place at the site since its discovery in the 1930s, relatively little has been published. Prior to 1974, only Green's (1962) general account of the site as a well-stratified archaeological, paleontological, and geological locality has dealt with the site at any length.
Since 1972, the Texas Tech University Museum's Lubbock Lake Project (LLP) has been concerned with detailed excavations at the site.
The focus has been on man's adaptation to ecological change at the site and on the Llano Estacado as a whole during the last 12,000 years.

Its approach has been interdisciplinary in nature, with aspects of the geology, pedology, biology, paleontology, zoology, botany, palynology, and archaeology all being viewed diachronically and synchronically.

Within this framework, an attempt has also been made to incorporate as much of the previous investigative data as possible. this resulted in a general symposium that brought together most, but not all, of the previous workers at the sita (Black, 1974) . Since then, each succeeding field season has added more details to an evergrowing and complex picture of past events at the site. Studies on the geology (C. Johnson, 1974; Stafford, 1977) , invertebrate paleontology (Compton, 1975; Pierce, 1975) , zooarchaeology (E. Johnson, 1974; , botany (Thompson, 1977) , and archaeology (E. Johnson and C. Johnson, 1976; Holliday, 1977; E. Johnson et al., 1977) are continuing.

In general, the work seems to have resulted in raore questions being formulated as each preceding one is answered. As a consequence, greater attention is being paid to specific problems within the current research framework. Concurrently, this has also increased the importance of reviewing the past investigative data more thoroughly. Of the two pre-Lubbock Lake Project collections (Wheat, 1974; Green, 1962 and Keiley, 1974) that are currently housed at The Museum of Texas Tech University (formerly the West Texas Museum of Texas Technological College), the latter's 1959-61 excavated material is by far the most extensive and best documented.

To date, three attempts aimed at integrating Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) collection and data with those from the Lubbock Lake Project have met with only limited success (E. E. Johnson et al., 1977; and Holliday, 1977) . Although virtually all the data are potentially usable, the primary problems involved with correlating Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) data with that of the Lubbock Lake Project have resulted from the differences in descriptive terminology, measurement, field and laboratory methods, and recording procedures. These problems are compounded by the complex sedimentological nature of the site. Different depositional regimes have resulted in localized and rapidly changing facies raaking area-wide stratigraphic correlations extremely difficult.

While new developments in theory, methods, and procedure are inherent in an ever-expanding discipline such as archaeology, integrating the past with the present can pose quite a problem in obtaining one comprehensive body of information. The results in such an effort, however, can be quite significant in terms of the added information. Hester's (1972) treatment and compilation of all the previous work at Blackwater Draw Locality No. 1 illustrates this very well.

Aside from adding information through re-analysis or correlation, a collection's research and educational value can only be preserved by proper management techniques. All too often collected raaterials are brought into a museum, analyzed according to contemporary standards, stored away, and then simply forgotten. Without a trained curatorial staff, the results can be disastrous. Lithics can become inadvertently "retouched," while raetals oxidize, pottery crurables, wood dries out and splinters, and bone fractures and disintegrates.

In addition, objects and original records can be misplaced or lost over a period of time. This unfortunately has been, in part, the case with Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) collection of material from the Lubbock Lake site. Since the mid-1960s, the material from these excavations has essentially been left in a "stored" state with the data base suffering as a result of collection deterioration, disorganization, and record loss. Although this might seem incredible, it is but a relatively minor example of an all too frequent occurrence which current museological methodology is seeking to eradicate (Dudley and Wilkinson, 1968; MacBeath and Gooding, 1969; Guthe, 1969; Burcaw, 1972) .

Thus, it is with this that the present study is concerned. The conservation, organization, correlation, and analysis of Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) collection is being viewed simultaneously from the two different perspectives of (1) modern museum collection manageraent practices, and (2) a research contribution through the addition of an existent, but until now, unusable data base. It is hoped that this will also serve to illustrate some of the methods by which an older museum collection can be revived as a potentially viable research and educational tool.

The Lubbock Lake site (41LU1) is located at the northeastern edge of the city of Lubbock, Texas (Fig. 1) , at latitude 33°37'13. 5" North, longitude 101°53'31.5" West (U.S.G.S. Lubbock West Quad 7.5 series, 1970) . It is situated within a Late Pleistocene entrenched meander loop of Yellowhouse Draw at a point where the drainage course changes from a southerly to easterly direction (Fig. 2 ). The present head of Yellowhouse Draw is readily traceable to within five miles of the Muleshoe National Wildlife Reserve, Bailey County, Texas. It raay have originated a few miles west of Portales, New Mexico, however, during the latter stages of the Pleistocene (E. . (Fig. 3) .

body_text.text: The Llano Estacado is a large, semi-isolated, physiographic province bounded to the west by the Pecos River Valley, to the north by the Canadian River Valley, and to the east by the dissection of a resistant Pliocene caprock. To the south around Ector and Midland counties, Texas, it grades almost imperceptibly into the limestone topography of the Edwards Plateau.

The surface of the Llano Estacado is dotted by numerous, shallow, wind-deflated basins (see Fig. 1 ) and has a continuous drainage system of draws which are generally little more than indistinct, low relief valleys until they approach the eastern margin of the escarpment front. Except for a few of the larger playas, little or no permanent water has existed within these features since the 1930s. At present, these playas and draws depend entirely on runoff from precipitation.

Initial discovery of the site occurred during the mid-1930s when large-scale dredging operations were conducted with Works Progress Administration (WPA) funds to creat an additional, municipal water supply for the city of Lubbock. Soon after the project had ceased, a Folsom point was picked up by two small boys on one of the two concentric spoil dikes ringing the newly created reservoir (Holden, 1974) .

Further investigation of the dikes also revealed the presence of bones frora extinct elephant and bison. Understandably the find generated a great deal of excitement since the remains of Early Man (Paleoindian) cultures had been only recently discovered and were vaguely known.
At the same time, a grant application for an area-wide archaeological reconnaissance was submitted by the West Texas Museura to the WPA.

Upon its approval, the test excavations were begun at the site in 1939 under the direction of Joe Ben Wheat and again in 1941. Although a high water table prevented successful excavation along the reservoir margins, an attempt was made to transect sorae of the older deposits.

One long trench (A) and a large pit (C), sorae 18 feet deep, were excavated to the southwest of the reservoir along the edge of the upper valley raargin fill. Artifacts, principally of the Ceramic and Archaic periods, were recovered and have been summarized by Wheat (1939; , Kelley (1974) , and Holliday (1977) .

During the subsequent war and post-war period of the 1940s, a local agricultural boom led to a substantial increase in the number of irrigation wells (Hopping, 1962:80-81) . This, in addition to the previous years of drought, brought about a rapid depletion of the underlying Ogallala aquifer system and resulted in a lowering of the water table. By 1948, the Lubbock Reservoir became dry and ceased to exist (Holden, 1974; Kelley, 1974) . In that same year Glenn L. Evans (Green, ms) . During that interval, a broad geologic section along the old reservoir cut was profiled in addition to test excavations at several selected stations around the site. Five distinct strata were identified and cultural material collected from several, although most of the work concentrated on the diatomite layer of the Folsom horizon (stratum 2). Only a brief account of the Folsom material was ever published (Sellard, 1952) .

In the spring of 1952, field classes in archaeology were conducted by W. C. Holden in the basal sands and gravels of stratum 1 along the east side of the reservoir bottom. No lithics were found, but several bones of bison and elephant were collected and stored in the old West Texas Museum of Texas Technological College (Green, ms) .

Work of a limited nature was resumed in 1957-58 as part of the Late Quaternary paleoecologic studies that were conducted throughout the West Texas area at that time. Samples of pollen, bone (for uranium content), and invertebrates were collected and analyzed (Wendorf, 1961) .

During the summer of 1959, more substantial excavations were carried out by F. E. Green (1962) with limited research funds provided by the West Texas Museum Association. Work centered on the upper level deposits at the southwest corner of the site in order to correlate the stratigraphy of Wheat's (1974) trench A with the section in the lower reservoir cut and reconstruct a raore complete sedimentary sequence (Green, ms) . This work served as the fulcrum for a National Science Foundation grant in 1960. The grant enabled Green (1962) , with Jane Holden Kelley (1974) , to further test some of the upper occupation levels discovered in 1959 in addition to sampling strata from lower deposits at several places around the site (Fig. 4) . Concomittant with this field work, Kelley (1974) also made a re-study of the archaeological materials collected by previous workers. Major excavation had ceased by November of 1960 although a minor amount of profiling and artifact collecting took piace in 1961. Summaries of this work can be found in two published articles (Green, 1962; Kelley, 1974) and an unpublished manuscript (Green, ms) .
In 1972, the current Lubbock Lake Project was initiated as an interdisciplinary research program of The Museum of Texas Tech v»

University. Initial efforts were aimed primarily at the testing of areas excavated by previous investigators in order to correlate the variously designated stratigraphic units. Most of the work was also centered on the Paleoindian levels at the site. Since 1974, however, several new excavation areas (Fig. 5 ) have been opened and have yielded archaeological features ranging from the Clovis to the Historic periods.

Initially all of the cultural and non-cultural material that was excavated from the 1959-61 operations was processed in the field by being bagged and labeled with a field number. For this, Green used geologic sample bags that were tagged with a serialized LL nuraber (e.g., LL-108) while Kelley made use of old West Texas Museum envelopes that were labeled with an entry number (e.g., Entry #96). Additionally, both Green and Kelley made frequent notations as to an object's identity, coordinates, or association. Larger objects, such as bison long bones, were temporarily placed in paper sacks or cardboard boxes (Green, personal communication) . Afterward, the material was transferred to and stored at the old West Texas Museum of Texas Technological College.

While at the Museum, additional trinomial accession/catalog numbers (e.g., 60-47-344) were given to the raaterial to replace the field designations. These were inked onto each object with black India ink.

Green characteristically coated his raaterial with a dash of white ink and then numbered in black on top of it. The cataloging process was completed, except for some of Kelley's material, by February of 1962 (Kelley, n.d.) , although approximately half of the entire collection had still not been individually numbered. Part of the associated object data was then entered onto specially designed catalog sheets (Fig. 6 ).

body_text.text: In 1970 the College Museum moved into its present structure located on the Texas Tech University campus at Fourth Street and Indiana Avenue, Lubbock, Texas. Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) Lubbock Lake site material was transferred with the rest of the Anthropology Division collections and stored in its original sacks.

Field maps and geologic profiles from the 1959-61 excavations were put 9 >i, \ 10 on file although several maps, photo negatives, and artifacts appear to be missing as a result of the museum transfer and/or previous or subsequent handling. During the period from 1973-74, several students began work with the 1959-61 collection, putting individual numbers on the objects that had previously been catalogued and adding several more 60-47 accession/catalog numbers to items that had previously been missed or separated from their inforraational context. Some of the bone raaterial was also washed and coated with preservatives. The lithic, raetal, shell, plant, and bone speciraens were then separated, segregated according to stratigraphic provenience, and placed in specimen storage cabinets.

In spite of this attempt at organization, however, distinctive organization and object relationships of the collection were still lacking due to a misunderstanding or lack of stratigraphic nomenclature, terminology of excavation areas and datums, and variable elevation designations (see Fig. 6 ). This is evident in the recent works of E. , Holliday (1977) , and E. Johnson et al. (1977) which have had only limited success in utilizing the data base.

The present study began in the latter part of 1976 and has consisted of four phases: (1) conservation of the collection, (2) recataloging, (3) data synthesis and correlation, and (4) deterraination of archaeological feature zones from each area of excavation. Each of these will be discussed in detail.

For over a decade and a half, most of Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) Lubbock Lake site collection of artifacts had been slowly deteriorating due to a lack of effective conservation measures, improper storage and handling, and variable environmental conditions. Ironically these classic symptoms of collection decay are the very reason for the development of modern collection manageraent practices as outlined by Plenderleith and Philippot (1960) , Werner (1963) , Organ (1968) , Guthe (1969) , Dowman (1970) , Plenderleith and Werner (1971) , Daifuku (1974) , Keck (1971-72) , and Majewski , among others. For this reason, the condition of the objects prior to treatment will de discussed.

After the excavations had ceased in 1961, very little, if any, of the material was washed even though approximately half of the entire collection had been numbered. Most attention had been paid to the lithic material. Only a few of the more fragile bones, particularly those from the older strata at the site, were treated with the preservative Alvar. In 1973-74, approximately 20% of the total collection was cleaned of matrix dirt and/or washed. Most of this consisted of faunal material; a smaller percentage of this was preserved in a variety of ways.

Of the remaining material that had not been conserved, deterioration was evident in a number of ways. A few potsherds were either broken or had crumbled; while parts of several ground micaceous sandstone (mano?) fragments were crumbling due to grain abrasion. Most affected, of course, were the raetal objects and faunal reraains due to the nature of their composition.

Many of the bones that had been grouped and boxed together under one 60-47 catalog number displayed breakage, fracturing, and disintegration (particularly along edge margins) caused by a combination of dryness and previous handling. This was particularly true of the more fragile bone from the older strata (1, 2, and 3). Figure 7 shows the condition of one such tray of Bison antiquus bone from stratum 2 as it appeared before any conservation measures were taken. Many of the older bones were also suffering from a "peel effect " (Fig. 10 ).

This occurs when the outer portions of the cortex begin to split along a series of roughly rectangular outlines as the bone dries out. Any disturbance of either the bone or dried-out matrix seems to result in a concave fracture along the Haversian canals below the surface and subsequent "peeling" of the outer bone cortex. This effect was observed in bones without any attached matrix, although it was more prevalent in those with matrix still attached.

This type of deterioration is particularly significant since many of the faunal remains from the Lubbock Lake site show signs of butchering activities in the form of cut marks and breakage (E. Johnson, 1976) . Even when the "peel effect" was not a problem, as in the case of sorae of the better preserved bone from the upper strata in the site, the bone was often partially or wholly obscured making identification or analysis in that condition difficult ( Fig. 12) . When matrix or fragility was not a factor, as in the case with some of the "fresh" looking bone from the Historic "muck" layer (5C LLP), several of the larger bones still showed extensive cracking or distortion (Fig. 8 ).

This was undoubtedly caused by the severe shifts in and unfavorable range of humidity (from 90% to 10% or less yearly) which often occurs in the Lubbock area. The former College Museum did not have facilities for environmental control. Bone and antler material are optimally kept at a stable, relative humidity of 55% (Daifuku, 1974:121) .

All of the metal objects were still in a highly unstable, corroded state. It is not known how rauch additional alteration through oxidation they may have undergone while in storage, except several originally shown in one piece on a map plot are now broken up, and every storage box contained metal oxide particles and powder. The hinge, bolt, squashed cans, square nails, and raiscellaneous unidentifiable items of either a steel, iron, or tin alloy were the raost affected and displayed, in raost cases a severe form of pitting from oxidation (Fig. 13 ). This buildup of oxidation was raassive on some pieces and had a characteristic dull yellow brown color indicating the presence of the hydrous iron oxide mineral, goethite (Gettens, 1964:563) . The presence of raagnetite was also suspected.

The stabilization of these metal oxides is raost imperative due to the nature of the corrosion cycle itself. The formation of rust on the metal surfaces, once started, usually continues until an eno crustation of 1-4 mm (10-40 A) is attained for the raetal oxide which then results in a protective oxide skin and restriction of further oxidation (Scully, 1975:1-11) . However, any abrasion of this rusted encrustation will regenerate the oxidation process resulting in continued downward pitting on the raetal's surface, or cavitation (Leidheiser, 1971:180) . The corrosion continues through a cathodic (hydrogen deposition) reaction called "hydrogen embrittlement" wherein generated hydrogen combines with atmospheric oxygen to form a surface of corrosive moisture film that can be as thin as 10,000 A (Ewing, 1938:24-25; Leidheiser, 1971:3-43) . This oxidation rate at roora temperature is logarithmic with time depending on the moisture film and thickness of oxide encrustation (Scully, 1975:11-13) .

The most serious form of rusting will take place when sodium chloride or other salts are present. The anodic areas of the metal will dissolve the salts forming a ferric chloride while the cathodic areas continue to liberate hydrogen forming sodiura hydroxide. Both compounds will then interact to form a continuous cycle of reactions where sodium chloride is regenerated and the process of rusting proceeds (Plenderleith and Werner, 1971:281-282) . The presence of salts in the rusting cycle of Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) metal material was easily noticable since the areas most affected by the oxidation process were those in which the matrix was still present.

The arid, alkaline soil types (i.e., brown soils with caliche horizons) of the Lubbock area are known to contain high amounts of chlorides and carbonates which are especially conducive to corrosion and pitting (Ewing, 1938:7-24; Leidheiser, 1971:209-211) . Later tests on the raetal for chlorides did indicate their presence in relatively high amounts.

The only metal objects that were not effected by oxidation to any significant degree were the brass (.45 caliber) cartridge casings. This is primarily due to their copper content (70% Cu, 30% Zn) which is raore stable than iron, lead, tin, or zinc even in the presence of salts because of its thermodynamic properties (Leidheiser, 1971:71) . A very thin, dark green film was observed on the shells and was probably one of a number of possible copper chloride corabinations (Gettens, 1964: 552 ). All of the shell casings did, however, display signs of stresscracking by their brittleness (one shell casing shattered when picked up by a student). This is caused by a dezincification of the shell which in turn causes minute fractures to develop both laterally and perpendicular to the metal itself during the corrosion process. This is generally the result of two agents: (1) the chemical environraent, particularly in the presence of ammonia, carbon dioxide, free oxygen, nitrates, carbonates, phosphates, and various alkalis; and/or (2) the presence of micro-organisms that produce acids which help germinate certain bacterial forms that often attack the intercrystalline structure itself (Leidheiser, 1971:79-233) . It is not known, however, what continuing effect the latter would have on a metal substrate once outside the medium of a soil environment.

The first step in the preservation process was to make sure that all the objects that had not been were cleaned of soil matrix. This was accomplished by picking the clumps of matrix off the objects with dental tools, gently scrubbing them in lukewarm tap water, and then allowing them to dry on wire mesh screens. Portions of the raatrix were saved in vials to aid in the identification of parent strata. Sorae of the bone material that had a matrix coating of an A-horizon soil resisted initial attempts at washing and had to be soaked for a short period in a weak solution of mild detergent and water.

This washing and matrix cleaning process was easily accoraplished in all but two instances-when Green coated a few of the bones with Alvar, or when they were sprayed with acrylics after numbering in 1973-74. The dirt matrix was, in effect, preserved on the bones that had not been washed or thoroughly cleaned making further cleaning extremely difficult, if not impossible. In this case the bones were repeatedly coated with acetone in an attempt to strip the outermost acrylic or alvar coating and then were soaked in lukewarm tap x^ater for varying periods and scrubbed. It should be noted that since the bones had only been coated, the soaking had the effect of helping to lift off the coating from within. This procedure was effective in stripping off the acrylics in raost cases, and the alvar in sorae, but could only be used on the stronger bone material from the upper strata at the site. It could not be used on the more fragile bones of the older deposits. Those were brushed with pure acetone several times with limited results.

Overall, the washing process was also responsible for the "discovery" of several utilized flakes, tools, and bones with distinctive butchering marks that had been otherwise raasked by the dirt raatrix.

After cleaning and air drying, all of the raaterial needing stabilization was preserved with a solution of gelva/acetone. Coramercially known as Vinac-B15, gelva is a polyvinyl acetate resin with a thermoplastic polymer with the following characteristics:

It is transparent, colorless, oderless, tasteless and non-toxic. A dry film has a high tensil strength ranging up to 5,000 pounds per square inch. It has a softening point of 131° centigrade. Heat and light stabilities are excellent and aging characteristics are good. At room temperature it is soluble in Acetone, Benzene, Acetaldehyde, Carbon Tetrachloride, Ethylene Dichloride, Trichlorethylene, Ethyl Acetate, Butyl Acetate, Collosolve, Mythyl Cellosolve, Toluene, and Cyclohexanone, Benzoldehyde, Aniline, Pyridine, It is not soluble in water, gasoline, mineral oils, vegetable oils, animal fats, turpentine, glycol, Glycerine, Isopropyl Ether, Carbon Bisulphide, Ethyl Silicate, N-Hexanol. Anhydrous alcohols are poor solvents but become good solvents when 5-10% water is added, based on the weight of the alcohols. These are Ethanol, N-Butanol, Isopropanol and Methanol (Jensen, 1966:50) .
It is economical and has a wide range of applications beyond bone material both in the lab and in the field. Perhaps raost iraportant, it is also reversible and can be stripped off at a later date.

The use of polyvinyl acetates (PVA) and related corapounds as a preservative had been known for some time (Woodbury, 1936) and is still recommended (Daifuku, 1974; Majewski, 1972-73) even though other products such as shellac, Duco/acetone, white glue/water, Seal Dry and other exotics have also been tested. All of the latter are used principally for bone preservation and, overall, possess less desirable or unknown qualities.

Shellac and Duco/acetone treatments offer a slightly improved tensile strength to the object, but both leave surface films and the former does not completely penetrate the bone (Lepper and Lewis, 1941:22-23) . The effects of both have been observed first hand on specimens from the Lubbock Lake Project that were so treated in 1973-75.

The former tends to allow the unpenetrated interior bone to slowly disintegrate while over a period of time the latter begins to crack and "peel." The former effect was also observed on an antelope skeleton (TTU-A903) from Green's (1962) raaterial that had had a very thick coat of Alvar brushed on it.

A solution of white glue (Elmer's) and water is recommended by Lewis and Redfield (1970:7-8) in the treatment of bone frora an archaeological context. While this may work with bone material of a recent age, it is not very effective with material frora early Holocene deposits (probably due to de-mineralization) and tends to last only a few years at best. Seal Dry (White, 1971:67) is an amber fluid used in lining masonry. Its penetration and added tensile strength appear to be good but more of its characteristics need further testing.

The results obtained with the gelva/acetone solution were excellent. Pieces of pottery, bone, and ground sandstone fragments that had been crumbling were significantly stabilized and greatly strengthened. A comparison of Figures 10 and9, and 12 and 11 show the condition, prior to and after treatment, of bone from both the lower and upper strata. Most items were given at least two treatments-first, in a thinner 10% solution to allow coraplete penetration, and second, in a 15% to 20% solution to effect a better coating. However, some of the "fresher" Historic bone required only one coating while some of the older bone, especially from stratum 2, required several.

When treated, all of the objects were completely emersed in the gelva solution until a lack of air bubbles indicated that the object was saturated. This was done to effect a complete penetration and hardening of the object in both the interior and exterior areas, because observations showed several bones preserved during 1973-74 had apparently only had superficial coatings leaving the interior portions susceptable to further deterioration through aging. After dipping in the gelva solution, each item was allowed to air dry on wire mesh screens. Most objects took less than fifteen minutes to dry before they could be handled. This is due, in part, to the qualities of gelva and the use of an acetone solvent. For saturated bone material that required a longer drying time, the process was speeded up with the aid of a small heat lamp. In all, over ten gallons of gelva solution were needed to preserve the entire collection.

The procedure for stabilizing the metal objects was somewhat different due to their corroded condition. After initial cleaning, all of the metal, except for the .45 caliber shell casings, were processed to neutralize the chlorides, which as indicated previously, could lead to further disintegration if left unchecked. At present the conservation facilities at The Museum of Texas Tech University are very meager. consequently the simplest procedure for stabilizing the metal was followed as outlined by Hamilton (1976:50-56 ; personal communication) and Plenderleith and Werner (1971:200-286) . The procedure used is as follows:
1. Boiling in a 1% solution of sodium hydroxide (caustic soda) 2. Several flushings with distilled water with repeated heating

and cooling to open the metal's capillaries and encourage diffusion of the chlorides 3. Testing for the presence of chlorides by drawing 10 cc of bath water, adding a few drops of dilute nitric acid, mixing well, and then adding 5 drops of a 2% silver nitrate solution (The silver nitrate test is good for indicating the presence of chlorides as low as 1 part per million by a distinctive opalescence of the solution [Plenderleith and Werner, 1971:201] .) 4. Repeated flushings until the test for chlorides produced a significantly reduced opalescence

The cloudiness of the first several tests indicated very high amounts of chlorides that were initially present and necessitated repeated flushings with deionized water. After the metal was significantly flushed of salts, it was allowed to air dry. Pieces with an intact core of metal were then coated with commercial naval jelly and allowed to sit for approximately one hour. This was done to neutralize both the additional rusting that occurred in the deionized water bath and remaining surface chlorides and leave a protective phosphate film to inhibit further cavitation.

The naval jelly was rinsed off with deionized water and the objects were blotted with a paper towel, allowed to air dry for about five minutes, and then immersed in pure acetone to speed up the drying process and prevent any additional rusting.

The metal was finally sealed with repeated dips in a thick solution of gelva until no air bubbles were emitted. Normally, a microcrystalline wax is used as a sealant (Hamilton, personal communication) because plastic coatings sometimes cloud up in the presence of water.

However, satisfactory results with the gelva were obtained due to the prior treatment and drying with acetone. Pol^rvinyl chlorides and acetates are known for their sealant qualities and corrosion protection X (Burns and Bradley, 1967:633-634) . A comparison of Figures 13 and 14 shows the metal both before and after treatment.

The same procedure was followed for the metal pieces without substantial cores, except that the pieces were soaked in the residual naval jelly/deionized water solution instead of being coated directly.
This was done mainly to help coat the pieces with a phosphate film since reduction of the metal oxides without a metal core is unnecessary.

The procedure used in treating the brass cartridges was somewhat simpler. All of the shell casings were dipped in naval jelly to reraove surface coatings of copper chlorides, cleaned in deionized water, dried with acetone, and preserved with gelva. The shell casings required a nuraber of coatings (6 to 10) before the air bubbles were no longer visible. This indicated that the casings were relatively porous and that an etching of the intercrystalline structure (dezincification) had occurred.

After all the objects needing stabilization were preserved, additional repair work on the broken lithics, potsherds, and bone raaterial was accomplished by using Duco cement. This was done only on those objects in which the 'breaks' were of recent origin (post-excavation).

Although Duco cement is not considered as a lasting, permanent bonding agent, its availability and expediency of repair time made it easier to use in dealing with the large quantities of broken material. This was especially true of the bone which, in some cases, had to have several fragments pieced together before its elemental morphology could be determined.

For bones that needed additional support, plaster of Paris was used as a filler, while added strengthening along breaks was achieved by using a Sear's brand of epoxy (£ 80605). Traditionally epoxy resins have not been fashionable in the repair of museum specimens since they are considered to be an irreversible, permanent bonding agent that has to be 'set' just right. However, Edmund (1976:43) has recently discovered that Dimethylforamide (also known as formdimethylamide) can be applied to epoxy resins to soften or dissolve them and allow repositioning or total cleaning of an object. Its vapour is poisonous, however, and contact with the skin must be avoided.

It should be noted that not all objects were impregnated with preservative and that selected items were completely omitted from any type of conservation treatment. In a classic paper on the conservation of museum collections, Werner (1963:600-604) has pointed out the hidden research potential of archaeological collections by illustrating several analytical applications that have yielded additional research data.

Since the time of this paper, the archaeological field, in particular, has witnessed a tremendous growth and refinement in both the quantitative and qualitative types of analysis (e.g., the chemical determination of organic trace substances frora lithic tool edges, the calibra-14 tion and accuracy of C dating, and bone tool technology, among others).

For this reason, each object in the collection was examined in detail to determine whether or not treatment would be beneficial to the overall research analysis. The objects (< 1% of the total collection) included in this group are bits of charcoal, burnedbone, carbonized plant (Xanthium sp.) molds, pottery, the edges of some stone tools, and the tips and edges of suspected bone tools.

As previously stated, Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) Lake site collection was catalogued with a trinomial accession number (e.g., 60-47-108) . This type of three-part registration number has been a standard procedure within museums for raany years (Guthe, 1969:38; Burcaw, 1972:74; Dudley and Wilkinson, 1968:19) . Its value lies priraarily in the fact that it is an expedient, practical raethod for labeling specimens, especially when there is a backlog.
Basically, each set of digits (from left to right) represents:

(1) the year of acquisition, (2) what collection the objects belong to, and (3) the individual object(s) that comprise the collection. The first two sets of numbers refer to the accession inforraation while the latter is actually the registration number.

When a single item is composed of several parts or several objects are grouped under a single set of data, the registration number can be further subdivided by placing a letter of the alphabet (i.e., a, b, c, etc.) after it for each individual component or object (Dudley and /" Wilkinson, 1968:19) . Several of the paleontologic speciraens and a few of the artifacts in Green's (1962) collection had been catalogued in this manner. The vast majority of this collection material. however, had been segregated according to a particular elevaticn depth and assigned one catalog (registration) number for the group (Fig. 6 ).
This had resulted in one or more potsherds, bison and other faunal bone, stone tools, flakes, and pieces of metal being represented by a single number.

For small museums with a limited or single theme collection, an accession/registration numbering system may be successfully employed as a substitute for a collection catalog (Guthe, 1969:42-43) . This type of system, however, begins to break down when collection numbers approach tens of thousands. Then, no matter how detailed or complete the object descriptions raay be, the records appropriate to a particular management or research problem will not be locatable except by a serial search through an entire file or files (Chenhall, 1975:8-16) . By developing a standardized catalog systera, however, each object within the collection(s) can be assigned to one or raore categories of an organized classification system so that it and its record may be associated with other objects or those related to it (Guthe, 1969:36) . In addition, the catalog system should not only cross-index categories of data that demand attention (e.g., donor names) but numerous areas of provenience, taxonomic classification, and descriptive data as well (Chenhall, 1975:9) .

In order to provide a more raanageable relationship with the raaterial that has recently (1973-77) been excavated from the Lubbock Lake site, both Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) collection was re-catalogued according to the system currently in use by the Anthropology Division of The Museum and, in particular, that of the Lubbock Lake Project. This was accomplished after the conservation process by (1) assembling all the data records and objects according to their former catalog series, (2) transferring all the object and contextural data onto SELGEM-based (Creighton, Packard, and Linn, 1972) computer catalog sheets, and (3) relabeling each item in India ink with a Texas Tech University (TTU) serial number (e.g., TTU-A395). Each ^ ^ 21 object was numbered only after the cleaning and preservation process, and the number was coated with an acrylic spray for added protection.
Previously, it had been observed that many of the former 60-47 catalog numbers either washed or peeled ( Fig. 7 ) off easily because of attached matrix.

The data categories of each catalog sheet ( Fig. 15 ) are divided into three sections, each of which pertain to the catalog, object, and provenience information, respectively. Examples of both the type of categories employed and how they are entered onto the catalog sheets are listed in Table 1 .

The first six categories deal with the numerical documentation of the object and its site and collection association. The acronym TTU (+051) identifies the object solely with The Museum of Texas Tech University and distinguishes it frora any other collection or institution on a nationwide basis (ASC supplement, 1973a:62-63) . This is followed by the Division (+052) symbol A, for Anthropology, and the serial catalog numbers (+053) which are assigned in number blocks (e.g., 500-999) to a particular site, groups of sites, or a collection.

Nurabers assigned in this fashion have the added benefit of grouping several years worth of accessioned collections into one coraposite serial. In this way, the 1959-61 collection raaterial will have its own distinctive sub-block of numbers within the total block utilized by the Lubbock Lake site materials. Altogether, categories +051, +052, and +053 also provide for a more systematic and better visual means of documenting each provenienced object or grouping of sirailar objects than the previous trinomial number. This is particularly true of items on loan or that have been illustrated or described in literature.

The second section of informational categories on each catalog sheet deal with the object's identity. Artifact (+479) and material (+480) categories used were developed "in house" and are shown in Tables 2 and 3 , respectively. Codes for the taxonomic classification of faunal remains, and their morphological elements are adapted from the Association of Systematic Collections (ASC supplement, 1973b:63-69) .

The latter are listed in Table 4 . Since most of the bone material that comprises the bulk of the collection had only been gone over in a cursory manner (see Fig. 6 ), a more complete identification and elemental breakdown was required. This was done with the aid of various texts (Olsen, 1964; Schmid, 1972; Gilbert, 1973; DeBlase and Martin, 1974; E. Johnson, 1976) , the LLP comparative oesteology collection, and professional consultation. In addition to identification, worked and modified bone were also listed under the artifact categories (Table 5) .
A total of 1,754 TTU numbers were used in the cataloging process on 11,785 individual objects, requiring over 1,000 man hours of work.

This represents an increase of 1,301 numbers over the previous 60-47 catalog serial which is primarily the result of detailing provenience data on individual artifacts. Approximately 5% of the total collection had been previously unnumbered. Catalog sheets were numerically ordered and placed into five, large ring binders that are now on file at The Museum of Texas Tech University. Originally, the catalog information was to have been reproduced here in table form, but the sheer volume of information was too prohibitive. A list of all the missing items is also on file at The Museum.

The major advantage in using the SELGEM-based catalog is that it contains a standardized system of classification within most categories while providing a certain amount of free-form flexibility in others.

In addition to accession inforraation, areas of provenience (e.g., Excavation unit, +490; and Coordinates, +494) which can vary frora site to site and even within one site over a long period of time, an extensive degree of latitude in both terminology and format is allowed.

Thus, distinctive attributes of both Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) excavations were retained during the cataloging process while other categories of informational data on the objects themselves were transferred into a standardized, coded format. This will now insure a continuity of classificatory relationships with other material excavated from the Lubbock Lake site, as well as the Anthropology Division collections as a whole. Within this format, the information can also be utilized in conjunction with an SPSS (Nie, Hull, Jenkin, Steinbrenner, and Bent, 1970) or any other specially designed computer package for specific analytical purposes.

While the number of data categories and format of the SELGEM package are not entirely suitable for all types of analysis (Gifford and Crader, 1977) , the system contains several favorable attributes for dealing with large volume collecticns cf varying nature. If ccmputer time costs should be too prohibitive, the coded catalog sheets can still be used to record informational and typological categories and provide for a relatively easy visual means of raanually searching the files. Certain aspects of data can also be used by raore than one scientific field.

Once all the preservation, repair work, and re-numbering of the collections was accomplished, each specimen or group of specimens were placed in zip-lock polyethylene bags (ranging from 2" x 3" to 8" x 10"), plastic or glass vials, or small cardboard specimen boxes. The more fragile items were packed in cotton. The larger bison bones were either packed in cardboard boxes or in wooden trays and laid on a bed of paper towels or cotton batting. The packing medium used most frequently was the polyethylene bags. They not only help to protect the speciraen frora breakage and seal it from atmospheric changes, but also allow for a quick, visual identification and location of a sought-after specimen. Each bag, vial, and box were also tagged with a small label citing the following information: TTU-A catalog number, object code, feature designation, elevation, excavation unit, stratum, and the former 60-47 catalog number. The latter was included to aid in the identification of specimens previously cited in the literature (E. Johnson, 1974 E. Johnson et al., 1977; Holliday, 1977) .

After packaging and labeling, the entire collection was stored in wooden drawers in steel specimen cabinets. In organizing the collection, a hierarchial format according to excavation area, stratum (from youngest to oldest), feature and non-feature material within a stratum, and grouping of similar objects (i.e., lithics, metal, etc.) from within a feature or non-feature was used. The current storage areas are kept in a controlled atmosphere of 40% + 5% relative huraidity and a temperature of 68 to 72 degrees Fahrenheit.
CHAPTER V

Originally, the focus of Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) 1959-61 excavations at the Lubbock Lake site was to incorporate, with further testing, the findings of Wheat (1939) and Evans and Meade (in Sellards, 1952) . The primary goal was to establish a composite of the geological and archaeological sequences. The present work of the Lubbock Lake Project has also concentrated on the documentation of the geological and archaeological deposits, in addition to other aspects such as; food economy, utilized resources, environraent, and behavior. The raajor differences between the two projects have been in the latter's raore current raethodology and scope of problera orientation, which, in general, reflect the advances raade within the archaeological field over the past decade. For this reason, a short discussion of the raethodology eraployed by each project will be presented.
Both the field technique and terminology of Green's and Kelley's work were typical of the era:

The basic excavation unit [Block] consisted of a tenfoot square, with two or more squares laid off in succession to form a trench. Corner stakes were given alphabetical letters, and with sub-numbers . . . used to differentiate one side of the trench from the other . . . Layers ranging from two to eight inches . . . [were reraoved] with trowels or hand picks, depending on the hardness of the raaterial being dug. The variability in thickness of the layers removed was the result of following natural stratification insofar as possible.

For purposes of plotting the depth of artifacts or other materials, a datum point was established on the first prominent stratigraphic contact, or on the surface of the lowest corner. Horizontal lines based on the datum point were affixed to both sides of the trench, and vertical measurements [in inches] were made from a detachable spring-tensioned line . . . Any raaterials encountered before the datum and horizontal lines were established were measured from the surface; and the surface contour, as well as stratigraphic cross-sections along trench walls, was plotted with respect to the horizontal lines. The horizontal location 24 ^ X 25 of artifacts . . . was determined by measurements from the corner stakes, and plotted on scaled [tenths of an inch] plan sheets. The field sample number as well as the depth was also recorded . . . Concentrations of bone, burned caliche rocks, or flint chips were usually bagged as one sample and plotted as one depth, except where depth variation was noticeable (Green, .

In addition, a plane table and alidade were used to map the locations of excavation blocks and to determine elevations. The primary elevation datum was based on an arbitrary value of 3,205 feet above sea level obtained from a well house foundation formerly located just outside the southwestern portion of the site proper (Green, ms:15) . A secondary datum for elevation and horizontal block triangulation was also established on the western side of the site at the location of the Singer Store historical marker ( Fig. 4) (Green, personal communication) . In addition to Green and Kelley, the excavation crew consisted of four other individuals ( Fig. 68) , though Green excavated a few blocks by himself (Green, personal communication) .

The Lubbock Lake Project has raade extensive use of the metric raeasurement standard and detailed recovery techniques. The central portion of the site has been gridded into 50 raeter square units that are referenced to a raain (U.S.G.S.) datum point called Bench Mark 1 (BM 1). A number of other sub-data reference points have also been placed throughout the site (Fig. 5 ). With the use of a transit, these points are utilized for gridding each excavation area into a number of one meter square units with designated coordinates that refer back to the main datum point. Excavation levels are dug in 5 cm levels within the smallest stratigraphic sub-unit. Elevation is referenced with a level and stadia rod to centiraeters above sea level, while the horizontal coordinates of in situ material are measured from the two unit walls that meet to forra a diagonal line to BM 1. Detailed notes and maps are recorded for each unit as well as excavation area. Additional machine testing is also used to establish intra-site stratigraphic correlations.

While Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) work has certainly produced enough data to be treated separately, it was felt that the data should be integrated in a manner compatible with that of the y X LLP's, since a continuity of informational design would be in the best interests of archaeological research and management of the collections.

As previously mentioned, all of the known records from the 1959-61 excavations were assembled during the cataloging process. These records include: the original (1962) catalog sheets, field notes, profile drawings, horizontal plot sheets, and field labels that are now on file at The Museum of Texas Tech University. When each object or set of objects was re-catalogued, the appropriate data from each record source was converted into a LLP type format on the catalog sheets ( Table 1 ). The informational categories contained on these sheets ( Fig. 15 ) not only helped to facilitate the correlation of Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) raaterial, but also synthesized the basic provenience data frora several sources onto one composite record. This had previously not been done (see Fig. 6 ).

In order to determine the relative accuracy of Green's primary elevation and how it would affect comparison to LLP material, several artifact concentrations and stratigraphic breaks were compared (after conversion to centiraeters) in Block C with the records from adjacent units excavated by the LLP in 1974 . The results, however, were too variable (between 1 to 9 cm higher) and probably due to either a differential breakout of stratigraphic boundaries (especially within the soil horizons) and/or a slight two-dimensional slope which can vary both cultural and stratigraphical boundaries several centimeters over just one meter of profile distance in that area (8).
