body_text.text: CHAPTER VI DATA SUMMARY

Since Wheat (1974) conducted his initial work at the Lubbock Lake site in 1939, a comprehensive geological fraraework has been viewed as the key to interpreting and understanding the nature of the site's cultural and environmental history. Evans (1949:11) was the first to systeraatically describe the deposits which were divided into five major strata of varying alluvial phases (Sellards, 1952:54 ).

Green (1962:110-120 ) refined Evans' section into seven different strata based on his own field work and correlation with Wheat's (1939) trenches (Fig. 4 ) on the west side of the site. This stratigraphic scheme was later modified by C. Johnson (1974) and again by as more data became available.

In the summer of 1976, Stafford (1977) conducted systeraatic trenching operations ( Fig. 16) , mapping, and detailed section descriptions in an attempt to finalize a composite of the stratigraphic sequence within the site proper and standardize the stratigraphic terminology.

At present Evans' (1949) original divisions of strata are still maintained; although Stafford (1977) has incorporated refinements from Green (1962) , Johnson (1974) , and , in addition to his own research. The culture-bearing late Quaternary valley fill of Yellowhouse Draw has now been formally divided by Stafford (1977) into the Late Wisconsin to Early Holocene Yellowhouse Draw Formation and the Holocene Lubbock Formation. The former includes strata 1, 2, and 3; while the latter includes strata 4 and 5, respectively.

The work of both Green (1962) and Stafford (1977) (1977) study is the most current and exhaustive to date, his work will be drawn on heavily in presenting a general outline of the site's geological sequence (Fig. 20) ; although comparisons to Green's (1962) work (Fig. 19 ) and concepts will be made.

The major geologic events responsible for shaping the geomorphic and stratigraphic setting at the site began after all Pliocene (Ogallala) alluviation had ceased. The generalized sequence, as modified from the work of Green (ras), C. Johnson (1974) , and Stafford (1977) , is as follows:

1. Erosion by wind deflation of the Pliocene surface to form a basin of, as yet, unknown (total) depth and extent 2. Basin filling by sands, clays, and interstratified dolomites of lacustrine origin (stratum 01) 3. Erosion of basin fill 01 If the erosion were by stream cutting, the deposits of Bed A would represent channel filling, and no close association with the basin deposits would be indicated.

Conversely, if erosion were by wind deflation, the sediments and fossils of Bed A could be ascribed to slope wash, and would tend to indicate that the basin deposits were the source of the fossils and were of Blancan age.
Stafford (1977:84-85 ) offers a slightly different set of hypotheses:

First, stratum 02 may have been a Blancan age intraformational channel gravel [and] . . . as such . . . would be a minor channel deposit within the aggrading Blancan lacustrine basin. Under this hypothesis, the strata 01/02 sands and dolomites would represent a local diastem; renewed deposition of stratum 01 sand and dolomite would have later covered stratum 02.

A second alternative is that the deposition of strata 01 and 02 may represent extreme end points of Blancan time. This . . . assumes that stratum 02 is a post-lacustrine channel deposit and not an intraformational conglomerate.
[T]his hypothesis depends upon: 1) the conclusion that the Blancan fauna was not reworked from an older unit; and 2) whether stratura 01 sands and dolomite may previously have overlain stratum 02.

At present there are no exposures where stratum 02 is overlain by stratum 01 sands and dolomites, although this in itself is insufficient proof to invalidate Stafford's first hypothesis. The taphonomic evidence, however, indicates that his second hypothesis may be more likely than the first. Green postulated that the 02 deposits may have been the result of reworking (1962:112) and water transport as suggested by characteristics of both the lithology (lower part) and faunal remains that seemed to rule against their origin as slope wash (ms:25). This is based upon (1) representation of several fossil genera, (2) smoothed and water-worn bones and bone fragments, (3) preponderance of fragments and isolated teeth, and (4) caliche pebble gravels (at the base) that are of well-rounded, moderately large, and fairly uniform size, suggesting some degree of transport or abrasion and sorting.
Not all of the evidence supports this contention, however, as noted by both Stafford (1977:85) and Green (ms:25) . Many of the complete bones recovered from stratum 02 display no signs of abrasion.

Green (ibid.) recovered the first and second phalanges of a small horse (cf. Nannipus) only a few feet apart as well as the unworn fragments of a large land tortoise (Geochelone sp.) from the upper part of his Bed A (middle unit-02) north of Block BB (Fig. 23 ). The turtle carapace and plastron pieces were only slightly scattered indicating a probable i^ situ burial.

It is also likely that the initial erosion of the stratum 01 basin deposits occurred by wind deflation and not by the cutting of a stream channel. This is based on (1) the removal of over ten meters (Fig. 21 The oldest deposits overlying stratum 02 is stratum 03. They consist of channel sands, gravels, and clays which disconformably overlie both strata 01 and 02 and are, in turn, unconformably overlain by younger sediments of strata 2, 3, or 5. Green did not encounter this unit during his own field work. This was probably due to the units small areal extent (1,200 square meters) and exposure to the south and east of the Area 5 excavation blocks (Fig. 24) . Stafford (1977:86-87) believes that the 03 deposit is a remnant alluvial terrace dating prior to ca. 15,000 years B.P. This is based on the stratigraphic and geomorphic context, as well as the Rancholabrean faunal elements (Bison antiguus and cf. Caraelops) recovered from the upper part of stratum 03.

Stratigraphically above stratum 03 and generally resting unconformably upon stratum 01 is the Yellowhouse Draw Formation. The oldest member, stratum 1, marks the first appearance of Paleoindian activity at the Lubbock Lake site. Stratum 1 (Fig. 20) is divided into four sub-units consisting of fluvial channel gravels (lA), sands (IB), silts and clays (IC), and a colluvial, gravelly clay (ID). Green (Fig. 19 ) recognized two zones, A and B, in stratum 1. Zone A correlates with substratum lA, while zone B would be equivalent to both substrata IB and IC; however, the uppermost portion of zone B was noted as having a different, clayey lithology (ms:28). Substratum ID was not observed by Green, probably due to its limited outcropping along the western side of Area 5 ( Fig. 24 ). This unit is tentatively considered as a colluvial shore facies of substratum IC (Stafford, 1977:101 ).

Green's (ms:28) division of stratum 1 into two zones is based on what he considers a change in depositional environment from a relatively high velocity, coursely loaded, stream to a lower velocity stream loaded only with finer grained sediments. This interpretation is fundamentally correct, although Stafford (1977:88-110) has demonstrated that each substratum is sediraentologically raore coraplex than previously thought and may, in some cases, be conteraporaneous depending upon a unit's position within the channel. Green (1962: (Fig. 20) into the 2A laminated diatomite, 2B diatomaceous earth, 2E sandy shore facies contemporaneous with 2A and 2B, 2C cienega, and terminal 2F sand wedge. Green (Fig. 19 ) recognized a similar, but slightly different profile. He divided substratum 2A into a lowermost pure diatomite zone (A) and a laminated diatomite zone (B) on the basis of what he considered a slight climatic change from unique, highly stabilized environmental conditions of pure diatoraite deposition to a raore flucuating seasonal deposition represented by laminated diatomite (Green, ms:33) . Both Green (ibid.) and Stafford (1977:112) attribute the basal diatomite to separate episodes of diatom accumulation interrupted only by occasional intercalated near-shore, sand laminae (Figs. 25, 26, 27) . Above this the diatomite is distinctly separated by alternating intervals of varying organic mud deposits.

Green's zone C is equivalent to substratura 2B, a raassive homogeneous unit of diatomaceous earth containing diatomite greatly diluted with mud. Together with substratum 2A, this unit makes up the bulk of stratum 2 within the site area. Green (ras:37) believed that substratum 2B "accumulated as raud and ooze under bog conditions."

This would infer both a time-stratigraphic separation (from substratum 2A) and a change in depositional regime as also suggested by other workers (Sellards, 1952; Johnson, 1974) . However, other evidence (Stafford, 1977:120-123) indicates that this may not be the case. The 2A/2B contact is generally irregular (vertical tonguing) and variable in thickness (Figs. 25, 26, 28) while exposures of substratum 2B occasionally contain laminae of diatomite and fossil plant beds. The implication is that the laminated (2A) diatomite raay have extended higher in the section before the bedding planes were subsequently destroyed or masked by bioturbation or pedogenic process (Stafford, 1977:134) .
Capping the diatomaceous deposits of stratum 2 is substratum 2C.

Commonly referred to as the "cienega," substratum 2C is an extensive, spring fed marsh deposit that is seen in the raajority of exposures at the site. The 2C cienega consists of two distinct lithologies-a lower zone of silty clays with abundant calcified plant fragments, and an upper zone containing vertical concentrations of plant rootlets
•v

and well-developed lithologic structure. Green (ms:39-40) recognized both of these lithologic intervals ( Fig. 28 ) and combined them as his zone A of stratum 3 (Fig. 19 ). The calcified, bulbous rootlets which make up most of the plant fragments in substratum 2C are identified by Green (Chester Rowells, personal communication, in Green, ms:112) as belonging to the family Cyperaceae, or sedges.

Stratigraphically above the cienega deposit ( Fig. 20) is substratum 2F, an alluvial brown and olive sand wedge that is restricted in its outcropping to Area 4 and some trenches west of Area 6 at the site (Fig. 5 ). Green encountered this unit ( (2) only a limited exposure of substratum 2F; and (3) the presence of a very weak cienega within stratum 3 (apart from substratum 2C) which developed on top of substratum 2F in Area 4 ( Fig. 29 ). Until recently it was thought that these olive sandy clays under the cienega in Area 5 ( Fig. 26 ) were a part of substratum 2F; however, Stafford (1977:130) has noted three distinguishing criteria: (1) texture of very fine sandy clays in olive 2C mud as opposed to clayey, fine to medium sands of substratum 2F; (2) consistently observed position of the olive 2C mud between the lower and upper 2C cienega where exposed;

and (3) thinness of the olive 2C unit in contrast to the often massive deposit of 2F sands. The olive color and slightly sandy texture of this 2C sub-unit is probably fortuitously deráved from its proximity to local Blancan sediments (02 upper raember) ( Fig. 23 ). The source of the 2F sands may likewise be of Blanco Formation sediments that were washed into the basin and mixed with the stratum 2 marsh/lake muds to produce a conformable contact (Stafford, 1977:129) . The bioturbated appearance of this contact, however, and its raassive alluvial character, make this unit distinctive. C. Johnson and Stafford (1976:15) It was this bone bed which produced the diagnostic Folsom point 14 found in situ by Evans and Meade (Sellards, 1952) . Two C dates were obtained on stratum 2 by the Texas Memorial Museum (TMM) group.

Charred bone collected at their Station M ( Fig. 4 ) gave a date of 9,883 + 350 years B.P. (C-558) (Libby, 1955) ; while snail shells (Helisoma and Lymnaea) from Station C yielded a date of 9,700 + 450 years B.P. (L-283g) (Broecker and Kelp, 1957 , 1961; Pierce, 1975; Compton, 1975) also infer a distinct increase in salinity and a decrease in available water between strata 2 and 3. Green (ms:39) believed that the lithology and origin of the substratum 2F sediments suggested a drought of limited duration which resulted in a reduction of vegetational cover and slope erosion. The evidence from substratura 3A would seem to indicate that this assumption is correct and that more arid conditions continued to prevail thereafter.

Overlying substratum 3A is substratum 3B. This sub-unit is lithologically similar to substratum 3A but differs in color (whiter) and in a more calcareous, platy structured sediment (Stafford, 1977: 142 Green (1962) assigned substrata 4A/4B, with 3C, to Antevs (1955) Altithermal stage of 7,500 to 4,000 years ago.

The date of 4,910 + 50 years B.P. (SMU-332, SMU-333) from substratum 3C, however, suggests that deposition of stratum 4 could have begun much later in time than postulated by Green. In addition, Stafford (1977:160) believes that the environment of deposition for stratum 4 is primarily fluvial although some aeolian accumulation may have been a factor to the west of the site. He cites: "(1) smallscale ripple cross-bedding, (2) clean sands interlaminated with clay,

(3) alternating clay and silt laminae, and (4) frequent lateral facies changes." In addition, the mottling effect observed in substratum 4A by Green is often discontinuous and not always interconnected which would preclude an origin entirely by burrowing aniraals (Stafford, 1977:157) . Some animal burrows have been observed in substratum 4A, however, it is not known if they are modern or fossil (Stafford, personal communication). Conforraably above the 4B calcic horizon is substratum 4C, a well-developed, very prorainent, buried A horizon. Although substratum 4C has been considered as a soil development within the previously deposited 4B sediments, C. Johnson (1974:96-97) gave it a separate sub-unit status. Stafford (1977) has chosen to keep this designation for the sake of terminological continuity. Green (1962) Resting unconformably upon stratum 4 is stratum 5. This unit is composed of aeolian, colluvial, fluvial, and cienega sediments characterized by recurring soil (A and B horizon) developments that are homologous to but more weakly developed than stratum 4 ( Fig. 20 ).

Stratum 5 is currently divided into three substrata: 5A, 5B, and 5C. This sequence represents two distinct lithologies within Yellowhouse Draw. The "upland" facies consists of substrata 5A and 5B valley slope soil developments; while substratum 5C consists of "lowland" paludal deposits of marsh clays (Stafford, 1977:169) . The latter has been referred to previously as the "muck" layer by Evans and Meade (in Sellards, 1952) and Green (1962) .

The terminological sub-divisions of stratum 5 are incongruous for the most part, and serve primarily to aid in labeling archaeological horizons. Green (Fig. 19 ) labeled the lower B horizon as his stratum 6 and zoned the above A horizon as 7a and the upperraost A and B soil horizons as 7b. No disconformity between substratum 5A soil and 5A has been seen and it is not known why Green lists one.

Green (1962:111 ) also considered the substratum 5C "muck" deposits to be an equivalent to his stratum 7. C. Johnson (1974) racognized a similar stratigraphic scheme although the terminology was rearranged considerably. These substrata designations were modified by and again by Stafford (1977) to their present form. The equivalents would be as follows: 1

As stated earlier, one of the raajor goals of the 1959-61 West Texas Museum excavations was to establish a coraprehensive framework on the nature of the archaeological deposits at the Lubbock Lake site. However, little of the cultural material excavated during that period has been reported. Green (1962: 119) briefly outlined two major living surfaces that he encountered near the top and raiddle of his stratum 6 (now substratum 5A) in Area 8. He (ms) refers to the upper one as "Occupation I" and the lower as "Occupational II."

Historic trash and debris attributable to the Singer Store occupation in his stratum 7 (now substratura 5B) are also mentioned (Green, 1962: 121). Kelley (1974) briefly reported on the material excavated from her blocks in Area 8 and attempted some comparisons to Green's work in that same area. The majority of her report, however, is concerned with the data from excavations at the site prior to 1959.

In addition to the material briefly reported upon frora Area 8, several other excavation areas were tested during the 1959-61 field period (Fig. 24 ). The geological sequence and cultural remains frora raost of these areas varied considerably frora those encountered in Area 8. For this reason, an in depth discussion of the raaterial recovered from each excavation area will be presented in this section. Detailed descriptions of each archaeological feature from an excavation area are listed in Appendix C and should be used as a suppleraent to the more generalized discussion of each area.

Of the two sets of excavation blocks that are located in this area, Green (ms) supervised the excavation of Blocks A , A, B, and C near the lower valley fill margin, while Kelley (1974) was responsible for the excavation of Blocks I, J, and K approximately ten raeters farther upslope (Fig. 24) . Features were defined on the basis of thin (2 to 6 cm) sterile soil zones between apparent living surfaces and show a linear but sloping distribution. To a certain degree, however, individual features are designated somewhat arbitrarily since some sterile soil zones do occur within parts of a feature, especially in Blocks A^ through C (Fig. 31 ). This would seem to suggest that some of the archaeological deposits in these features are a result of discreet, occupational activities which are temporally so close that they are, for the most part, indistinguishable. For this reason, only those levels of occupation with distinctively separate space intervals were identified as features.
Green (1962) uncovered two Garza occupations from his Blocks A through C. The lower occupation (II), feature GA8-7, is situated just above the highest lens of colluvium in substratum 5A (Fig. 31 ).

It consists of a living surface strewn with lithics and remains of ,lf, and bison ( Fig. 44 ). Several distinct activity areas are wo. A few broken tools and utilized flakes were recovered throughout the scatter. Sixteen Bison bison skulls were found clustered in Block A and part of Block A^. Green (1962; ms) suggested that this feature represented some ceremonial or ritualistic significance and was not a random heap of discarded bones. This suggestion was based on the roughly circular arrangeraent of the skulls, the paucity of other bones, and the intact braincase on several well preserved specimens (indicating that the brain was not utilized) ( Fig. 49 ). However, when viewed within the whole of feature GA8-7 ( Fig. 44 ), the skulls are not entirely isolated; other more mundane activities had occurred within and nearby. In addition, virtually all of the skulls have had their nasals, premaxillae, and maxillae detached while several have portions of the horn cores and skull parts missing.
Most of this debris was recovered within Block A, but not raapped.

Both the arrangement and type of breakage pattern would, therefore, suggest a more functional activity, such as raarrow processing and possibly some brain removal, rather than a ceremonial activity. This processing hypothesis is corroborated by the post cranial elements found scattered throughout Blocks B and C. Only four individuals are represented; and, except for most of the distal limb eleraents, all of the bone material has been heavily damaged and broken. In addition to a relatively high frequency of rib (100), shaft (92), and bone scrap (50) fragments, many of the vertebral, long bone, and other post cranial elements exhibit breakage patterns characteristic of marrow extraction and bone grease manufacture (Schmid, 1972; Bonnichson, 1973; Vehik, 1977 : Noe-Hygarrd, 1977 . Two other features, GA8-6 and GA8-8, located within Blocks A through C, may be associated with this lower Garza occupation.

Feature GA8-8 consists of a camp hearth and a scatter of Bison bison elements (Fig. 50) . It is restricted to Block C and is separated from the lowest part of GA8-7 in that block by approximately 5 cra of sterile soil.. However, it raay still be contemporaneous with the lower part of GA8-7 in Block A^ (Fig. 31 ). Green (ms) believed this to be the case. One very large caliche cobble (now raissing) had been Walton et al., 1961:58) .

The other feature, GA8-6, consists of sparsely distributed bison and bone scrap debris (Fig. 43) . It is separated frora the top of GA8-7 by a thin, sterile soil interval that becoraes thicker as one proceeds from east to west in Blocks A, B, and C ( Fig. 31 ). This raay indicate that the bulk of this feature is still to be found upslope and towards the west. In any case, no diagnostic material has been recovered, and its association to both the upper (GA8-4) and lower (GA8-7) Graza occupations remains unclear.

Features KA8-5 and KA8-6 may also correlate with the lower Garza occupation of GA8-7. Feature KA8-5 consists of the edge of a hearth exposed in the northwest corner of Block K (Fig. 53 ). The reraainder of this hearth (FA8-6) was excavated by the LLP in 1974 (E. Johnson et al., 1977 . Fig. 37a ), Harrell (TTU-A113; see Fig. 38a ), and Lott (TTU-A201) were found. The latter is a locally known and informally named point type (E. Johnson et al., 1977) . Green (1962:120) previously reported only the presence of Harrell points for this feature.

Of the five scrapers, or fragments thereof, recovered, all were made on flakes. Only two specimens were not broken. One is a particularly well-made, plano-convex, snub-nosed scraper (TTU-A399; see two metate fragments (TTU-A458); five pieces of hematite/limonite, one (TTU-A154) of which has been ground; seven pieces of mollusc shell; two broken tubular bone beads (TTU-A218); 196 pieces of burned silicified caliche; and 32 potsherd consisting of two different types.

Most of the sherds are of a thick-walled, coarsely tempered, heavily brushed black utility ware that is locally known, but as of yet untyped (Green, 1962; Kelley, 1974; E. Johnson et al., 1977) . This type of thin-walled micaceous ware is considered to be characteristic of Plains Apache (Campbell, 1976) . Gunnerson (1969) recovered a similar pottery type, termed Ocate Micaceous, from northeastern New Mexico, which was believed to Jicarilla Apache dating from approximately A.D. 1600 to A.D. 1750.
In addition, several iteras found on the surface of fill piles are thought to have come from this occupational level (Green, n.d.) .
These include one crude end scraper (TTU-A5; see grease was a priraary activity, although soraa marrow extraction raay have taken place (Bonnichson, 1973; Vehik, 1977) .

The camp hearth, feature GA8-5, associated with feature GA8-4 is located in Block A ( The archaeological deposits in substratum 5B are characterized by the presence of several metal objects. Green (1962; ras) believed that they represented refuse and trash items frora Singer's Store (Fig. 33 ), a frontier trading post believed to have been located near the Lubbock Lake site from about 1881 until 1886 (Holden, 1974:12) .

A plot of the vertical artifact distribution in Blocks A through C, however, shows that this material comes from two separate zones ( Fig. 31 ). Feature GA8-2 in the lower part of substratum 5B consists of two brass shell casings, a potsherd of raicaceous "Apache"

blackware, and a flake and a side scraper (TTU-A380; see Fig. 35) of Edwards Plateau chert. Both Green (n.d.) and Kelley (1974:65) refer to the shells as being .38 caliber revolver cartridges, although their length and diameter fit the type for the .45 caliber cartridges used with the Colt .45 handgun (Logan, 1959:139 (Connor, 1962; Holden, 1962) . At present, it cannot be determined if the metal and charcoal are a result of buffalo hunter, Singer's Store, or cowboy occupation, although the material probably dates from that period (ca. 1874 to 1890). One spent .50 caliber Sharp's rifle cartridge (TTU-A12356) found in the same substratum by the LLP this past summer (1977) would seem to indicate that the buffalo hunters were once active in this area of the site.

The presence of "Apache" pottery within this feature horizon is interesting. Its stratigraphic position in relation to two .45 caliber shell casings found in Block A would suggest that it should slightly pre-date or be contemporaneous with the metal items. Presuming that this placement is correct, the aboriginal association should be that of Comanche as they were known to be in the area from about 1720 until 1876 (Collins, 1971) . It is difficult to formulate any substantive hypotheses based on the recovery of one potsherd, although two obvious postulates can be entertained. The Comanche contacts with the Apache may have brought in the later type of pottery;
or, perhaps, some Apache peoples raay have traveled into this area from
time to time, particularly after the exit of the Comanche in 1876.

Holden (in Connor, 1962:55-56) relates the story of one informant who recalled a crowd of cowboys, Mexicans, and a half dozen Apache Indians milling about the front of Singer's store located "on the southwest side of a lake which formed the headwaters of the Yellow House." If this account is accurate, then the latter hypothesis is plausible. It would also indicate that the objects of white civilization from this horizon may, indeed, be frora activities related to George Singer's store.

The relationship between features GA8-2 and GA8-1 is not clear, although feature GA8-1 is stratigraphically above the former in the substratum 5B soil (Fig. 31 ). Most of the material recovered from feature GA8-1 consists of badly corroded square nails and raetal cans.
Green (ras) believed that these iteras were also part of the Singer Area 7

Two Blocks, P and Q, were excavated in this area along the western raargin of the reservoir cut (Fig. 24) . The stratigraphic sequence is virtually identical to that in Area 8, except that the A horizon in substratum 5A is markedly thicker and more developed (Fig. 34) . The stratigraphic break between substrata 5B and 5A is also more abrupt and distinctly separated by a colluvial pebble lens (Fig. 32) . The distribution of artifacts and feature zones (Fig. 32) is comparable to the sequence in Blocks A through C in Area 8 (Fig. 31) . Two occupational zones are apparent in stratum 4, one at the 4B/4C contact, feature GA7-8; and another at the top of the 4C, feature GA7-7. The cultural material recovered form both features is very meager, but several items from them are missing from the collections. Only one heavily patinated flake of Edwards Plateau chert is representative of feature GA7-8; while feature GA7-7 consists of several pieces of burned silicified caliche, and several broken and processed bones of a juvenile bison.

The most abundant archaeological material come from substratum 5A in this area. Two features, GA7-5 and GA7-6, are concentrated within the lower half of this stratigraphic unit, overlapping both the 5A colluvium and 5A soil (Fig. 32) . Feature (GA7-5 consists of a two-tiered hearth in Block P (see Fig. 34 ). Unfortunately, the vertical plot of the artifact elevations from this feature shows little distinction between the two levels ( One mandibular body fragment (TTU-A22364) has had its dentary symphysis and ascending ramus chopped off in addition to the length of the inferior body margin, exposing the dental batteris. This

type of damage is identical to that reported by Noe-Nygaard (1977: 223, Fig. 223 ) on red deer mandibles from the mesolithic Star Carr site in England. It is believed to be a breakage pattern characteristic cf marrow extraction activities.

Green (ms) equated this occupational zone of features (GA7-5 and GA7-6 with his "Occupation II" (feature GA8-7) in Area 8. Although several of the bone breakage and butchering techniques are very similar, there are no diagnostic artifacts to which a temporal association can be definitively equated. Any correlation would have to be considered as tentative. The material recovered from feature 14 GA7-5 for C dating may help to indicate whether any kind of association can be assigned.
The next feature, GA7-4, extends throughout both blocks ( Fig. 58) and is separated from the lower occupational horizon by several centimeters of culturally sterile soil (Fig. 32) . Holden, 1974) .

This would tentatively affiliate this feature with the Apache period of occupation since: (1) the Apache were known to have been in this area from A.D. 1525 to about A.D.1720 (Gunnerson, 1960; Collins, 1971) ;
and (2) its stratigraphic position which would roughly make it contemporaneous with other Apache occupations at the site, although no raodern horse elements have been associated with them.

The uppermost zone of occupation in substratum 5A is feature GA7-3. This feature consists of a small, shallow hearth and scatter of camp debris (Fig. 57) . The artifacts within this feature show a linear distribution in relation to the hearth (Fig. 32) and are believed to be part of the living surface directly associated with it. The hearth had apparently contained some ash, charcoal, and a few pieces of burned caliche (Fig. 34) . articulated along the left side. The uppermost feature zone, GA7-1, consists solely of square nails, cans and other pieces of metal, except for one fragment of a wolf (Canis lupus) jaw (Fig. 55 ).

Three Blocks, E, F, and B, were excavated in this area along the inside margin of the reservoir cut on the western side of the site (Fig. 24) . The strata sampled include the lower section (strata 1, 2, 3, and 4) not excavated in Areas 8 or 7 (Fig. 24) .

No cultural materials were found in stratum 1, although elements of . One mammoth pelvis uncovered at the stratum 1/2 contact in Block E (Fig. 28 ) was subsequently destroyed by "pothunters" before it could be removed (Green, ras:81) . Virtually all of the feature zones in this area are clustered within stratum 2 ( Two features, GA12-3 and GA12-4, were delineated in the lower and upper part of substratum 2C, respectively (Fig. 82 ). This was based on the slight lithologic differences in the two zones recorded for substratum 2C in this area (Fig. 28) . The two features may be related, but this is difficult to ascertain without first-hand field Johnson (1977) has demonstrated that many of the bird, reptile.
and small mammals (particularly rabbit) recovered in the Paleoindian horizons at the site were probably an occasional dietary item.

Green (ms) believed that the lithic remains recovered from substratum 2C were probably part of Sellards' (1952) "Portales Complex" (Fig. 28) . While this typological assignment is still basically correct, Wheat (1972) has re-defined some of the types and terminology. Holliday (1977) has determined frora surface raaterial that several Late Paleoindian cultures were probably present at the site, although the raost common cultural type found ±n situ appears to be that of Firstview. One Firstview-like projectile point (TTU-A863; see Fig. 76 ) was recovered from feature GA12-3. It has been extensively re-worked along both lateral margins which has significantly altered its original shape; however, projected raeasureraent indices indicate that it would typologically be along the lines of Firstview (Holliday, 1977:24) . Most of the re-working had produced a serrated edge indicating secondary use as a knife, probably in butchering. Wheat (1977) obtained a sirailar pattern of modification on Kersey points from the Jurgens site. Other lithics associated with feature GA12-3 include a core (TTU-A974; see Fig. 79a ), a broken scraper (TTU-A973; see Fig. 79c ), a fragment of ironstained, raicacecus sandstone, one utilized and three waste flakes. In addition, a broken incised tubular bone bead (TTU-A916) was recovered.

The lithics in feature GA12-2 consist of two end scrapers, TTU-A23959 ( Fig. 78 ) and TTU-A822 ( Fig. 83) , a flake scraper (TTU-A873; see Fig. 46a ), a biface fragment (TTU-A887; see Fig. 77 ) that may have once been a scraper, a biface base (TTU-A926; see Fig. 73b ),
and one utilized and two waste flakes. Green (ms) , 1977) .
Most of the mapped lithics from this feature are in Figure 81 .
Three other lithic items frora substratum 2C that cannot be stratigraphically assigned to either feature GA12-3 or GA12-2 include
•V ^ a spokeshave (TTU-A960; see Fig. 75 ) partially coated with a black resinous substance, a utilized flake (TTU-A972; see Fig. 38b ), and a piece of debitage.

The only feature not contained within stratum 2 in this area is GA12-1 in the lower part of substrata 3A/B (Fig. 82 ). This feature contains a variety of faunal remains, many of which are probably noncultural; however, both the distribution and breakage pattern of the antelope (Antilocapra americana) and bison (Bison antiquus) suggests sorae cultural modification (Fig. 80) . No lithics are associated with this feature, although one flake (LLP, 1976-133) , now missing, was found just to the north of this area in Trench 59 ( Fig. 16) at approxiraately the same level as the antelope and bison. While somewhat meager in remains, this feature is particularly significant considering the fact that evidence of human activity has been extremely scanty in this stratigraphic unit.

Green (ms:95) originally identified the bison recovered from stratum 3 as belonging to Bison occidentalis (Fig. 91) ; however, E. has determined that all extinct bison remains at the site are Bison antiquus. Both Wilson (1974) and E. give excellent summaries of bison development and evolution pertaining to this problem of speciation.

Non-featured raaterial recovered from stratum 3 consists of a rib fragment from the top of substratum 3B, and carbonized, cockleburr (Xanthium sp.) molds (TTU-A789) from substratum 3C at the strat 3/4 contact.
Two Blocks, M and N, were excavated in this area (Fig. 24) .
The strata sampled were very similar to that encountered in Area 12, although substratum 2C is not represented in the sequence (Fig. 29) .

It has been replaced by part of a 2F sand wedge. Only two features were delineated in this area. The lower one, GA4-2, in substratum 2F consists of several elements of Bison antiquus, representing one (perhaps two) individual (Fig. 89) . This feature is the fringe area of a kill/btuchering locale whose raajor concentration (Fig. 90) is located several meters to the southwest (Fig. 5 ) (E. .

No diagnostic artifacts are yet associated with this particular bone bed, but the geological evidence (Stafford, 1977) would suggest either a very late Paleoindian or early Archaic period procurement activity.

The upper feature, GA4-1, is located within the lower half of substratum 3B. Evidence of cultural activity is raeager, but present in the form of a few burned caliche pebbles and one, utilized, quartzite flake (TTU-A984; see Fig. 73a ). Like Area 12, the artifacts are few but significant since they indicate that some human occupation had occurred in this particular area of the site (Fig. 24) . This is something that has been rarely seen in other areas at the site.

Aside from Area 8, Area 5 was the raost extensively excavated and profiled during the 1959-61 operations. Unfortunately, there are no surviving records on the materail recovered beyond several geologic profiles and notations on vertical relationships. The strata sampled were 1, 2, 3, and 5, in addition to two pre-archaeological units, 02 and 01 ( Fig. 23) . Stratum 3 is unconformably overlain by substratum 5C as a result of modern channel cutting and raarsh deposition. Some truncated 4A deposits, not shown in Figure 23 , are also present on the west side of the "island," a colloquially-used term for this area (see configuration in Fig. 24 ). Two sets of Blocks were excavated, S, T, and U on the tip of the island, and AA through HH farther back along the eastem raargin (Fig. 5) . Originally, the testing in this area was to have consisted of Blocks, S, T, and U, but the other blocks were later added in attempting to locate the source of fossilized bone found outcropping in stratum 1.

Except for part of a raaramoth (Elephas sp.) centrum, the only material recovered from stratum 1 consisted of re-worked Blancan fossils. As stated earlier in the section on geology, the source of these fossils was located in two Beds (A and B) of stratum 02 (Fig. 23) Another probable kill/butchering locale is represented in feature GA5-3 located at the contact between substrata 2B/2A (Fig. 26 ).

Elements of two bison (Bison antiquus) were found. At least one of these individuals was a juvenile, probably a four year old, as indicated by one, unfused radius caput (Koch, 1935) . Green (ms) states that two articulated forelimbs (metatarsals to third phalanges) of the immature animal were found lying across each other. This, in addition to the lack of other elements, would suggest that this placement was a result of human (butchering) activity. This is corroborated by the recovery of a side scraper (TTU 60-47-279; see The major outcrops for these two formations occur mainly in the larger playa lake basins to the west and northwest of Lubbock (Brand, 1953) . . In addition, the recovery of Garza and Harrell points from the lower LLP feature (FA5-6), and Washita and Lott points from the upper (FA5-2) suggests a slightly different temporal and cultural affiliation (Holliday, 1977) . Green (ras) show identical breakage and damage as that reported by E. Johnson . The rest of the intact metacarpal was found nearby (Green, ms) .

Most of the recovered bison elements came from Blocks AA and BB ( Fig. 23) and were associated with several burned caliche pebbles (Green, ms) . This would suggest that a localized, processing substation may have been present. This suggestion is corroborated by the recovery of several large, burned silicified caliche cobbles that were probably used as anvils for breaking bone in marrow extraction. E. has determined that one of the raajor food processing activities of features FA5-2 and FA5-6 was that of marrow production. Two probable battering stones are also present.

One side scraper recovered frora this substratum by an amateur is shown in Figure 79b .

body_text.text: Three Blocks, W, X, and Y, were excavated in this area (Fig. 24) .

The strata sampled includes the entire sequence of stratum 1 and only the lower part of stratum 2 (Fig. 27) . No lithic raaterial was found in stratuml, although several late Pleistocene animal genera were recovered. These are discussed in detail by E. Wheat (1939; and Evans and Meade (in Sellards, 1952 ), Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) fieldwork has contributed an important data base. This information has been expanded upon by the current Lubbock Lake Project and has resulted in some revision of Green's (1962) original findings and concepts; most notable are the geology (Stafford, 1977) and the zooarchaelogy (E. . Many of the previous misconceptions have been pointed out, although it should be noted that much of Green's (1962) work has been the basis from which the present concepts have grown. As Green (ms:6) appropriately stated in the introduction of his manuscript of the investigations prior to 1959:

With additional research on any subject, it is all too easy to be critical of misconceptions or erroneous statements of past workers . . . when inconsistencies are pointed out . . . it is done for the purpose of showing the norraal course of progress, and with the full understanding that past misconceptions which become evident in the light of present data were not due to lack of judgment, but due to the lack of availability of information.

The correlation of the archaeological material recovered during the 1959-61 excavations has added considerable insight into the nature of man's activities and adaptive strategies at the site. This is particularly evident in a recent paper (E. Johnson et al., 1977) on the Garza occupation at the site. The inclusion of Green's (1962) material from Area 8 helped to define the different utilization of the site environs by the Garza peoples. The information presented in this study has also documented in detail several micro-activity areas within the Garza occupations in addition to several raacro-activity areas in different substrata and culture horizons that have not been previously sampled. Specifically, these include the Paleoindian levels in Area 12, upper strata deposits in Area 7, stratum 4 deposits in Area 8, and stratum 3 deposits in Areas 4 and 12.

The analysis of Green's (1962) and Kelley's (1974) collection has also generated more data on the individual objects. A number of stone tools, utilized flakes, and types of butchering and bone processing damage have now been identified which had not been noted at the time of excavation. This, in turn, has added some new insights into the interpretation of the raaterial and will provide a basis for additional research in determining the findings of this study in relation to the overall picture of past events at the site. The documentation and conservation of the collection according to raodern museum management techniques will greatly benefit any future studies by providing for an easier access to the information, records and raaterial. As a revived and viable research collection, the objects and their associated data can be utilized as an educational mediura, both today and in the future. As Daifuku (1974:124) has said: 'Live' as against 'dead' storage is one of the keys to the well being of a museum. There is little sense in having collections which cannot be used owing to lack of records, or to inability to locate them, or in keeping them under conditions which lead to their deterioration. x: (1977) \/ H/\ LLP 1977

Lithic materials are identified as to source whenever possible and are given color codes according to the Rock-Color Chart (G.S.A., 1975) . Except for silicified caliche (which outcrops at the Lubbock Lake site), no naturally occurring outcrops of raw material are known to the Lubbock area. Holliday (1977:82-84) gives a concise, updated review of the known outcrop sources for the lithic materials found at the site.

The bone tool and butchering pattern terminology (see Table 5) is adapted from E. . Lithic descriptions and terminology are based on Sanger et al. (1970) and Tixier (1974) . Object Its color is very light (N8) to light (N7) gray.

A total of 292 flakes and pieces of debitage were recovered. All were broken or fragmentary except for one large (L47; W30) chalcedony flake (TTU-A244). Of the total, 64 (or 22%) showed some degree of utilization and included some flakes of very small sixe (MDlO-20).
The results of utilization are observable in a number of edge damage categories. Those observed were:
(1) steep (> 45° edge angle) retouch and/or damage flake scars-26 specimens;
(2) alternate steep damage flake scars with two or more edge notches-2 specimens;

(3) steep damage flake scars on one side with two or more notches-3 specimens; (4) steep damage flake scars with one edge notch-1 specimen; (5) alternate steep damage flake scars with one edge notch-1 specimen;

(6) unifacial damage scars (< 45° edge angle)-12 specimens; (7) unifacial damage scars with one edge notch-5 specimens; (8) unifacial damage scars with two edge notches-1 specimen; (9) alternate edge damage scars-4 specimens; (10) very fine, minute damage scars-8 specimens; and (11) no edge damage, but two edge notches-1 specimen. Edge notching is prominent and in most cases, appears to be the result of intentional retouch. However, the intended function or activity responsible for this phenomenon is uncertain.

All of the utilized flakes and debitage were from Edwards Plateau chert except for one flake (TTU-A244) made of chalcedony. Edwards Plateau chert was the most preferred (96.5%) lithic material for the 292 specimens.
Color variants are: (1) yellowish gray (5Y8/1) to light olive gray (5Y6/1)-216 specimens;
(2) medium dark gray (N4) with medium bluish gray (5B5/1) specks-19 specimens;
(3) light brownish gray (5YR6/1)-10 specimens;

(4) light olive gray (5Y6/1) with pale reddish brown (10R5/4) to grayish red (10R4/2) diffuse mottling from heat-treatment-28 specimens; (5) dusk yellow (5Y6/4) to yellowish gray (5Y7/2)-11 specimens (one heattreated); (6) brownish gray (5YR4/1)-2 specimens; and (7) variable-very light gray (N8) to light olive gray (5Y6/1) to brownish gray (5YR4/1)~1 specimen. The bone is very similar in characteristics of preservation and raay have been re-worked frora 4C deposits upslope. However, this is conjecture at this time. More of the lower 5A deposits need to be field tested before definitive conclusions can be made. The same type of bone preservation also occurs stratigraphically higher in 5A and raay also be the result of a weak Ochrept (Fig. 32) . The hearth in this feature actually consists of two superimposed separate hearths. Unfortunately, no distinction between the upper and lower levels can be made based upon the vertical plot of bones and artifacts from within these levels (Fig. 32) . Therefore, although treated singularly, it is recognized that the two levels probably represent spatially separate events and activities of short duration. Other than the vertical profile in Figure 34 , little is known of the characteristics or conf iguration of the lower level. The only raapped items are those recorded from the upper most level (Fig. 63) , and as such, any discussion of horizontal placement is restricted to that level. Charcoal from the lowermost level of the hearth 14 has produced a C date of 160 + 90 years B.P. (Fig. 34 ). The flake scraper (TTU-A22397) is made from a grayish orange (10YR7/4) chert. It is rather small (L15; W20; T2) and displays extremely steep (approximately 90 ), but very fine, pressure retouch and micro-wear damage along the distal margin that has resulted in a slightly scalloped or concave edge. FIGREF0.text: Lubbock Lake site showing earlier basin deposits by Green

FIGREF1.text: Draw traverses a southeasterly course to a point a few miles down from the site proper where the valley walls rapidly become steeper and more distinct. At this juncture within the city of Lubbock at Mackenzie State Park, Blackwater Draw joins with Yellowhouse Draw to form Yellowhouse Canyon, a major tributary of the Double Mountain Fork of the Brazos River. The Yellowhouse Canyon system forms a major portion of the drainage pattern that cuts across the relatively flat, treeless, escarpment called the Llano Estacado or Southern High Plains

FIGREF2.text: Grayson Meade, under the direction of E. H. Sellards from the Texas Memorial Museum, began field work at the site that continued 6 p until 1951

FIGREF3.text: ) of 01 basin sediments to the present elevation of 968.8 meters for the 02 deposits; (2) the areal and basin-like extent of the eroded deposits (Stafford, 1977; see Fig. 63); (3) the lack of any major trending features indicative of major stream incision; and (4) the interpretation of the (pre-lacustrine) lowermost pebble unit of stratum 02 as a minor, probably intermittant, channel wash inlet. The latter are most common to the major wind deflated playas on the Llano Estacado today and would explain the limited areal extent of the known 02 deposits (Stafford, 1977). Many of the well-rounded bone fragments deposited with stratum 02 may have been derived from the previously eroded 01 deposits. Green (ms:22) recovered a few poorly preserved and unidentifiable bone fragments from stratum 01 in Blocks F and G (Area 12). Intermittent exposure to the eleraents before final burial by channel wash or lacustrine sediraents would have similarly abraded some of the bone material and, undoubtedly, had an effect on the caliche gravels at the base of stratum 02. Stafford (1977:81) has recently observed the rapid fracturing and weathering of 1-5 cm blocks of "bedrock" dolomite and concludes: "The dolomitic clasts give the anomalous appearance of having traveled long distances downstream whereas their true source raay have been only meters away." It is most plausible then that the pebble conglomerate is derived from a very localized source of 01 dolomite just to the east and may have undergone only liraited raechanical weathering to attain their degree of abrasion.

FIGREF5.text: Fig. 29) in his excavations of Blocks M and N (Area 4) and correlated it with an olive colored sandy clay found under the "cienega" development off the tip of Area 5 (Fig. 25). He (ms:38) believed that these sands "washed in from the valley slopes, bringing an end to the deposition of stratum 2," and subsequently assigned the (2F) deposits to zone D of stratum 2(Fig. 19). Green's juxtaposed positioning of substratum 2C and 2F is easily understood and undoubtedly the result of observing: (1) coincidentally similar appearing lithology between the lower gleyed sands of 2F and lower 2C of Area 5(Fig. 26);

FIGREF6.text: were able to substantiate both the lithological context and stratigraphic position of substratum 2F by tracing the entire lowland to (thickening) upland facies sequence during mechanical tesing of Yellowhouse Draw some 3.5 km south of the site. The thickness of substratum 2F increases from 0.15 to 0.22 raeters in Blocks M and N (Fig. 29) to 0.5 raeters in the LLP excavation units of Area 4 (Fig. 4) and Trench 83 (Fig. 16) indicating a similar facies change. Stafford (1977:130) considers substratum 2F as very late 2C to pre-stratum 3 in age. The absolute time for deposition of stratura 2 (exclusive of substratum 2F) is bracketed by several radiometric dates. The base of substratum 2A has been dated, in sequential order, at 10,930 + 90 years B.P. (SMU-292; snails), 10,530 + 90 years B.P. (SMU-285; humates), 10,060 + 70 years B.P. (SMU-251; humates), and 7,840 + 170 years B.P. (SMU-247; residue frora SMU-251). These samples bracket an extensive Folsom period bone bed found throughout the site in the first organic zones above the basal pure diatomite of substratum 2A.

FIGREF7.text: The upper geological deposits tested in these blocks consisted of substrata 4B and 4C, in addition to the coraplete "upland" valley facies of stratum 5. The stratigraphic sequence within each set of blocks was virtually identical except for minor variations in sub-unit thickness(Figs. 17, 33)  and elevation. This was confirmed by LLP test excavations adjacent to Blocks C and K in 1974. Due to the limited nature of the test excavations, however, the variations in thickness and elevation prevented precise intra-area correlation between the feature raaterial recovered from each block area. At the time no profiles of Blocks I, J, or K had existed.As part of this study, three large geologic profiles (Trenches 104 through 106) were mechanically excavated along the southern margins ofGreen's and Kelley's blocks (Fig. 16). The resulting geologic cross-section (Fig. 69)shows a raore precise relationship between the individual substrata and slope increment (1 vertical meter:20 horizontal meters) for this area. All of the substrata are easily traced along the length of the profile, except for the upper part of substratum 5B in Trench 104. At this point some slightly different characteristics of soil formation and an unusual amount of disturbance made differentiation and substrata delineation extremely difficult.Kelley (n.d.)  observed the same kind of phenomenon in trying to assign Green's stratigraphic scheme to her own blocks. This is reflected in Kelley's profile of Block K (Fig. 17).At present, there are no profiles of Blocks I and J known to exist; however, a satisfactory reconstruction of their stratigraphic "^ sequence was extrapolated by utilizing various field notations on stratigraphic boundaries(Kelley, n.d.), the cross-section profile inFigure 69, and a scaled profile photograph of the northeast corner of Block I(Fig. 67). Both the projected profile and artifact distribution for Blocks I, J, and K are shown inFigure 18. The artifact distribution for Blocks A. , A, B, and C is taken directly from Green's (n.d.) profile of those blocks and is shown inFigure 31.A comparison of Figure 18 and 31 shows a very similar vertical distribution of artifacts and feature zonation. Stratum 4 yielded the smallest amount of archaeological material and no diagnostic artifacts. Green did not recover any raaterial frora substratum 4B. Kelley recovered a large pebble of burned silicified caliche, a flake of Edwards Plateau chert, and part of a Morrison quartzite cobblefrom Block K. Two occupational zones, GA8-11 at the 4B/4C contact and GA8-10 in the uppermost part of 4C, are located in Blocks A^ through C(Fig. 31). A similar pattern can be seen in Blocks K and I, except that the artifact distribution within substratum 4C is more variable(Fig. 18). Three occupational zones have been defined: KA8-12 at the 4B/4C contact, KA8-11 within the middle of 4C, and KA8-10 at the top of 4C.All of the stratum 4 features share the same characteristics.They are sparsely distributed and contain raostly burned silicified caliche, a few lithics (primarily of Edwards Plateau chert), and some bone scrap (sometimes burned). A few bone elements have been identified as that of bison. The artifacts recovered from features GA8-11 and KA8-12 at the 4B/4C contact include 63 pieces of burned silicified caliche, 16 small flakes and pieces of debitage, one large, heat-treated flake, and a side scraper (TTU-A781; see Fig. 52);while those from feature KA8-11 in the middle of 4C include eight pieces of burned caliche, two retouch/resharpening flakes, and three utilized flakes. Features GA8-10 and KA8-10 from the uppermost part of 4C produced 11 pieces of burned silicified caliche, a small broken flake scraper (TTU-A763; seeFig. 48a), two flecks of charcoal, eight retouch/resharpening flakes, and a mano fragment (TTU-A23852) of bumed silicified caliche. Six of the flakes (TTU-A23777) were found in a pile at the western corner of Block K(Fig. 17)and probably represent an individual tool retouch/resharpening station.Although somewhat meager, the artifact and faunal remains of substratum 4C suggest that the repeated occupational zones are representative of a series of encampment activities.A similar sequence is seen in the lower half of substratum 5Awhere a number of caliche gravel lenses are present(Fig. 69). A number of artifact zones have been discreetly separated frora each other by the lenses of slope-wash colluviura(Figs. 18, 31). The cultural material recovered was sparse in both quantity and distribution. Feature material consists primarily of bone fragments of Bison bison, a few flakes, and pieces of burned silcified caliche.A snub-nosed thumbnail scraper (TTU-A716; seeFig. 51) was recovered from Block A of feature GA8-9. Green (ms) originally placed this item at the 4B/4C contact, but a re-check of the field measurements indicates that a placement at the base of substratum 5A is more appropriate.The upper feature zones of substratum 5A show evidence of a more intense, repeated aboriginal occupation(Figs. 18, 31).

The rest of the vertebral and limb elements are not duplicated, however, and are probably of one, definitely butchered individual. Several lithic scatters are also concentrated in Block A^, representing more than one chipping station.

FIGREF9.text: The lithics items recovered from feature GA8-7 include four projectile points (three, Garza; and one, Harrell), four scrapers, twelve utilized flakes, one preform (TTU-A557; seeFig. 45b), 156 waste flakes and debitage, and three sandstone metate fragments, in addition to a few miscellaneous items. Virtually all of the lithic material is of Edwards Plateau chert. Exceptions are the metate fragments and four pieces of obsidian. Other than the utilized flakes, all of the tools had been broken and apparently discarded. The three Garza points consist of a longitudinal mid-section (TTU-A603) fragment, a unifacially flaked base (TTU-A602; see Fig. 37b), and both halves of a complete point (TTU-A633; see Fig. 45a) that had been broken at the mid-section and found within a short distance of each other in Block A . The corner tang of a Harrell point (TTU-A515) and possible mid-section fragment (TTU-A654) of another, untyped point were also recovered. One narrow and relatively high-backed (keeled) side scraper (TTU-A430; see Fig. 46b) shows extensive retouch and damage along both margins. Several utilized flakes that are characterized by small size and a relatively thick, concavo-convex, cross-section are shown in Figure 47b, c, and d, respectively. One metate fragment (TTU-A608) displays a slight reddish stain along its concave surface that may have been from grinding hematite, although none was recovered from this feature. Other miscellaneous tools include a unifacially flaked tip fragment (TTU-A516; see Fig. 37c), and a finished bone awl (TTU-A561; see Fig. 47a) fashioned from a split section of maramal rib. Its tip had apparently broken during use, and the tool discarded.

FIGREF11.text: Fig. 40), while the other is a side scraper made from a cortex flake struck off of a cobble (TTU-A96; seeFig. 41). A total of 292 flakes and pieces of debitage were recovered. All were broken or fragmentary except for one large, utilized chalcedony flake (TTU-A244). Of the total, some 22% showed some degree of utilization and included some flakes of very small size. The amount and type of edge damage categoies are variable and would suggest that a variety of cutting and scraping activities on different substrates took place (Wilsem, 1968; Tringham et al., 1974). Most of the utilized and non-utilized flakes were distributed throughout the blocks within areas of concentration. One small cluster near the border of Block 3/A, however, contained 42.5% of the total flakes and pieces of debitage recovered in this feature. Utilized flakes numbered 36.5% of the total lithics found in this concentration. Other lithic and miscellaneous raaterials recovered include a biface (TTU-A221; see Fig. 39); a groundstone fragment (TTU-A226);

FIGREF13.text: Fig. 70) made from a large, decortification flake; four potsherds of the thick, brushed utility ware; four flakes; and one piece of raollusc shell. All of the lithic material is of Edwards Plateau chert. Food debris scattered across the floor of feature GA8-4 consisted of a canid, possibly coyote (Canis cf. latrans), pronghorn antelope (Antilocapra americana), ornate box turtle (Terrapene ornata), and at least two bison (Bison bison). The most numerous elements are of bison although all of the bones, except the distal limb elements, were thoroughly broken apart. Many display characteristic butchering and breakage patterns. As expected the long bone shaft and rib fragments comprise the bulk of broken eleraents, numbering about 150 pieces each. Virtually all of the fragments are under 100 mm in length, with the majority between 40 and 60 mm in maximum dimension. This would suggest that the raanufacture of bone

FIGREF14.text: Fig. 35). The material recovered from it is fairly representative of the artifacts scattered throughout this living surface. They include 23 flakes and debitage, four utilized flakes, five potsherds of the two types previously discussed, 117 pieces of burned silicified caliche, and a few miscellaneous elements and bone scrap of bison. Except for the caliche, none of the items show any sign of charring and, thus, were thrown into the hearth after it had already cooled. from the upper slope of Blocks I and K (feature KA8-4) for this upper Garza occupation are somewhat meager. They consist of seven pieces of burned caliche; one piece of obsidian; a potsherd of the untyped, thick, brush ware; and some miscellaneous bone of bison and pronghom antelope. Above this Garza occupation in the top part of substratum 5A another zone of occupation, features GA8-3 and KA8-3, may be associated. No diagnostic artifacts have been recovered. The raaterial consists of waste flakes, burned caliche, bison, and non-bison faunal debris.

FIGREF15.text: Store trash. All of the nails and cans, however, are restricted to the latest forming A horizon of this stratigraphic unit and are nondiagnostic for the most part since they are items that could have been used in the Lubbock area to well past the turn of the century.Most of the tin plating of cans for the manufacture of canned goods did not occur in the United States until around 1891(Burns and Bradley,   1967:12). Any conclusions or even postulates concerning the occupational material from substratum 5B, however, must be regarded as tentative until raore precise, raicro-stratigraphic work and analysis is carried out.

FIGREF16.text: Fig. 32). Not rauch is known about the lower hearth level beyond the cross-section profile in Figure 34. At present, there are no raaps or records of its horizontal configuration or contents. The upper hearth level and associated habitational floor is shown in Figure 63. Two concentrations of burned caliche and burned and unburned bone are noticable within the hearth area. It is not known whether two adjacent or one large, subsequently disturbed hearth is represented; however, the presence of a large quantity of unburned raaterial suggests that it had been partially exhumed after its initial use and later filled with refuse. The majority of bone material strewn throughout the hearth and upper living floor consists of at least three bison. The raost numerous elements are vertebrae and rear distal limb elements. All of the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae display breakage from the butchering process, presumably from the removal of the hump meat and ligaments. Several have also had portions of the centrum chopped away. All of the long bones, including metapodials, have had their shafts broken and are represented only by the distal or proximal segments. As expected, bone shaft fragments are relatively numerous (>^ 200 pieces). This would suggest that the manufacture of bone grease had been a prominent activity. Elements represented by a small number of fragments include ribs, pelves, and skull parts. One left inominate (TTU-A22276) shows extensive butchering damage including multiple blow marks to the internal wall of the acetabulum (for detachment of the femur). The same butchering technique was seen in two specimens from feature GA8-7 in Area 8. Other, unmapped, faunal material includes wolf (Canis lupus), coyote (Canis latrans), box turtle (Terrapene ornata), and mud turtle (Kinosternon flavescens). All of the recovered lithics come from within the hearth area. They consist of a groundstone (metate?) fragment, a broken side scraper (TTU-A22373; see Fig. 65) of Alibates chert, two utilized flakes, and five small waste flakes. Charcoal from the lowermost hearth level was dated at 160 + 90 years B.P. (1-208, in Trautman and Walton, 1962:40). Green (ms) considered this date to be too young in view of the geological evidence. Some contamination may have resulted from its close proximity to the edge of the reservoir cut. Three samples each of charcoal and bumed bone have been taken from an upper, middle, and lower zone of the hearth and are slated for 14 future C processing. The dates should provide an interesting bracket for both hearth level occupations and comparison to the 14 earlier C date. Feature GA7-6 is undoubtedly the living surface extension of feature GA7-5, although to what extent it is not clear. Most of the artifacts have a highly variable elevation range (Fig. 32) and cannot be distinctly associated with either hearth level in feature GA7-5. The lithics consist of one large, silicified caliche chopper, a core of silicified caliche, three utilized flakes, a tiny flake scraper, and one small flake of chalcedony. The chopper (TTU-A22408; seeFig. 64) and one utilized flake (TTU-A22407) were recovered in Block P at about the same elevation as the lower hearth level in feature GA7-5 and raay be associated. Bison elements make up virtually all of the bones recovered in feature GA7-6 and exhibit the same types of butchering and processing damage as in feature GA7-5.

FIGREF17.text: Most of the mapped bone (Bison bison) frora this feature is distributed throughout three areas of concentraton that may represent individual processing places. Except for some tarsals and phalanges, all of the recovered elements are well fragmented. This is particularly tme of the long bones and metapodials that have had their diaphyses completely broken apart and are represented only by distal and proximal segments. The relatively high amount of shaft fragments(138)and pieces of bone scrap (about 175) would again seem to suggest, in view of the other bone breakage, that bone grease manufacture was a prime activity(Bonnichson, 1973). The presence of numerous, burned caliche pebbles and calcined bone indicates that a hearth had been nearby.The lithics from this feature consist of a broken biface (TTU-A22294; seeFig. 61), a broken side scraper, a flake, and two pieces of debitage. In addition, one extensively retouched decortication flake (TTU-A22237; seeFig. 60) with a slight, pointed projection at one end was recovered. Its function may have been as a scraping implement, but this is not certain since virtually all the former edge had been re-worked. The side scraper (TTU-A22374; seeFig. 62) is of a unknown, very smooth, cryptocrystalline chert that has been bifacially flaked to produce what may have been finer "grips." If this assumption is correct, then these bifacial facets would form a perfect right-handed fit. No culturally diagnostic artifacts were encountered; however, the recovery of a raodern horse (Equus caballus) tooth frora the middle of feature GA7-4 in Block Q dates this occupational horizon to at least post A.D. 1540, i.e., after the arrival of the Spanish conquistadors (

FIGREF18.text: However, there are no longer records of this or any other material being recovered. The objects from the rest of the feature includeapossible mano fragraent, a utilized flake (TTU-A22310; see Fig. 59), and a few broken elements of bison. No cultural equivalents are postulated for this feature at this time. The cultural deposits in substratum 5B are identical in both material content and vertical distribution as Blocks A^ through C in Area 8. The lower feature zone, GA7-2, consists only of a few burned caliche pebbles, broken Bison bison elements, a tibia frora a cottontail (Sylvilagus sp.), a butchered, partial skeleton of a pronghom antelope (Antilocapra araericana) (see Fig. 56). One discarded butchering unit found in Block P contained several articulated cervical and thoracic vertebrae. The latter were also associated with several ribs (some broken near the proximal end)

FIGREF20.text: Fig. 82), a sequence that is almost identical to that encountered in LLP excavation Area 6(Holliday, 1977).Feature GA12-5 consists of a bison kill/butchering locale in the lowermost part of substratum 2B almost at the 2B/2A contact. Three distinct piles of disarticulated Bison antiquus bone representing one individual per pile were raapped (Fig. 86). One side scraper (TTU-A922; see Fig. 87) was found in Block F a meter and a half away from one pile. Unfortunately, raost of the bones recovered from this feature have suffered considerable post-excavation damage and depletion, and no specific butchering pattems can be discussed. At least one individual was an adult and another a juvenile, probably a young four year old as based on the epiphysial closing schedule of several elements(Koch, 1935). The recovery of one fetal phalange (TTU-A23731) indicates the presence of at least one calf-bearing female. Although no diagnostic artifacts were found, the stratigraphic position of this feature would place it within the Plainview period horizon at the site as defined by Holliday(1977)  andGreen (ms).An activity zone, feature GA12-4, is also located at the top of substratum 2B. No cultural affiliations can be assigned to this feature, although it is probably a result of Late Paleoindian (Firstview culture?) period activity(Holliday, 1977). Only one flake and a broken flake scraper (TTU-A921) were found in addition to several small animals. One notable aspect of this feature is the recovery of an intact, articulated pronghom antelope skeleton (TTU-A903; seeFig. 85) found in Block G.Green's (ms:37)  description of the animal's in situ posture indicates that the individual had died a natural death. A chopper or core (TTU 58-72-2; seeFig. 88) of chemically altered, silicified caliche was found near this area and may be associated with this feature. Green (ms) recovered the tool, now missing from the collections, from the uppermost six inches of substratum 2B while profiling near the location of Trench 47 (Fig. 16)in 1958. It was also associated with some antelope remains.

FIGREF21.text: testing. Most of the faunal remains are the same throughout substratum 2C. They include a few bone fragments of extinct bison (Bison antiquus) and elements of pronghom antelope (Antilocapra americana), coyote (Canis latrans), bobcat (Lynx rufus), badger (Taxidea taxus), rabbit (Lepus sp., L^ califomicus, Sylvilagus sp., and ^ auduboni), prairie dog (Cynomys lucovicianus), duck (Anas cf. streperas, A. cf. americana, A. cf. discors or carolinensis), and turtle (Terrapene sp., T. ornata, and Kinostemon flavescens) (E. Johnson, 1976). Many of the elements, particularly the small mammal long bones are broken up and may represent the scattered remnants of food debris. This assumption is supported by the recovery of lithic artifacts normally associated with camp or occupational activities;and a modern analog to the type of cienega deposits represented by substratum 2C that has been observed by Stafford (personal communication) to be capable of supporting such activities. In addition, E.

FIGREF22.text: , now missing, approximately one foot away. It was apparently of olive gray chert (Edwards Plateau?) with a striking platform and percussion bulb on the narrow end that indicated it was struck frora a prepared core(Green, ms). A lanceolate biface (TTU 60-47-285; seeFig. 71), now missing, of light gray (Edwards Plateau?) chert was also recovered from Block T. Green (ms) believed it to be a knife and stated that it had been "thinned by percussion flaking and edged by pressure chipping." The chronostratigraphic position of this feature would make it an equivalent to the Plainview period horizon at the site(Holliday, 1977). Green (ms) had correctly ascribed this feature to the Plainview culture based on an estimate of the time interval for deposition of the laminated diatomite between this bone bed level and the lower Folsom horizon.Two other probable bison kill/butchering locales were sampled in the upper part of substratimi 2B (feature GA5-2) and lower part of substratum 2C (feature GA5-1) (Fig. 26). Feature GA5-1 is probably the extension of a butchered juvenile skeleton recovered in FA5-8 (E.. Unfortunately, most of the skeletal elements from both features GA5-2 and GA5-1 have suffered greatly from past storage conditions and little can be said of butchering patterns or techniques. No diagnostic artifacts were recovered, but the stratigraphic context would suggest a late Paleoindian, probably Firstview, activity(Holliday, 1977). Curiously enough, juvenile bison elements have been present in features GA5-3, GA5-2, and GA5-1 and raay represent a behavioral selectivity for the younger aniraals and their more tender meat.•% Stratum 3 yielded little material and no features were delineated. Only one broken distal femur of a pronghorn antelope (Antilocapra americana) and a flake (TTU-A23608) of chemically altered chert were recovered. The most extensive cultural deposits containing bone and lithic material were recovered frora substratura 5C. Unfortunately, very little provenience information on the material exists. Three lithic items from Block EE with associated provenience were featured as GA5-4. They include a metate fragraent, biface fragment, and a piece of obsidian debitage. The metate fragment (TTU-A23725) is of a very vine grained sandstone of the type which has been observed to outcrop in exposures of the Cretaceous Duck Creek and Kiamiche Formations.

Unfortunately, the lack of data associated with the bone material recovered by Green (ms) precluded any sort of direct correlation since another processing station, feature FA5-2, lies stratigraphically above FA5-6. Although the butchering techniques and breakage patterns are sirailar, both features are spatially separate activities.
